[Option4] Consumers who are not regular readers of Kitchen magazine will be attracted to the cookware by the Kitchen name
[Option5] Kitchen is one of the most prestigious cooking-related magazines

problem: Comcorp Shipping Clerk: Last week, no shipments of building supplies were sent out on Friday. The five specially ordered shipments sent out last week were sent out on Thursday, and each of those specially ordered shipments consisted entirely of building supplies.   Four shipments were sent to Truax Construction last week, none of which consisted of building supplies.If the shipping clerk's statements are true, which of the following must also be true?
options: [Option1] All of Comcorp's shipments of building supplies last week were specially ordered
[Option2] None of Comcorp's shipments sent on Friday of last week was sent to Truax Construction
[Option3] None of the shipments sent by Comcorp to Truax Construction last week was specially ordered
[Option4] None of Comcorp's shipments sent on Thursday of last week was sent to Truax Construction
[Option5] All of Comcorp's shipments of building supplies last week were sent out on Thursday

problem: Advertisement: Ten years ago, the Cormond Hotel's lobby was carpeted with Duratex carpet while the lobby of a nearby hotel was being carpeted with our competitor's most durable carpet. Today, after a decade in which the two hotels have had similar amounts of foot traffic through their lobbies, that other hotel is having to replace the worn-out carpeting near its   lobby entrances, whereas the Cormond's Duratex carpeting has years of wear left in it.Which of the following, if true, most seriously weakens the force of the advertisement's evidence for concluding that Duratex carpet is more durable than the carpet of its competitor?
options: [Option1] The lobby of the Cormond Hotel has five different entrances, but the lobby of the other hotel has only two
[Option2] The carpet of the Cormond Hotel's lobby is not the most durable carpet that Duratex manufactures
[Option3] The other hotel has a popular restaurant that can be reached from outside without walking through the hotel lobby
[Option4] The carpet that is being used to replace carpeting near the other hotel's lobby entrances is not Duratex carpet
[Option5] There is a third hotel near the other two that has not replaced the Duratex carpet in its lobby for more than 15 years

problem: An experiment was done in which human subjects recognize a pattern within a matrix of abstract designs and then select another design that completes that pattern. The results of the experiment were surprising. The lowest expenditure of energy in   neurons in the brain was found in those subjects who performed most successfully in the experiments.Which of the following hypotheses best accounts for the findings of the experiment?
options: [Option1] The neurons of the brain react less when a subject is trying to recognize patterns than when the subject is doing other kinds of reasoning
[Option2] Those who performed best in the experiment experienced more satisfaction when working with abstract patterns than did those who performed less well
[Option3] People who are better at abstract pattern recognition have more energy-efficient neural connections
[Option4] The energy expenditure of the subjects' brains increases when a design that completes the initially recognized pattern is determined
[Option5] The task of completing a given design is more capably performed by athletes, whose energy expenditure is lower when they are at rest

problem: In Colorado subalpine meadows, nonnative dandelions co-occur with a native flower, the larkspur. Bumblebees visit both species, creating the potential for interactions between the two species with respect to pollination. In a recent study, researchers selected 16 plots containing both species; all dandelions were removed from eight plots; the remaining eight control plots were left undisturbed. The control plots yielded significantly more larkspur   seeds than the dandelion-free plots, leading the researchers to conclude that the presence of dandelions facilitates pollination (and hence seed production) in the native species by attracting more pollinators to the mixed plots.Which of the following, if true, most seriously undermines the researchers' reasoning?
options: [Option1] Bumblebees preferentially visit dandelions over larkspurs in mixed plots
[Option2] In mixed plots, pollinators can transfer pollen from one species to another to augment seed production
[Option3] If left unchecked, nonnative species like dandelions quickly crowd out native species
[Option4] Seed germination is a more reliable measure of a species' fitness than seed production
[Option5] Soil disturbances can result in fewer blooms, and hence lower seed production

problem: The spacing of the four holes on a fragment of a bone flute excavated at a Neanderthal campsite is just what is required to play the third through sixth notes of the diatonic scale—the seven-note musical scale used in much of Western music since the   Renaissance. Musicologists therefore hypothesize that the diatonic musical scale was developed and used thousands of years before it was adopted by Western musicians.Which of the following, if true, most strongly supports the hypothesis?
options: [Option1] Bone flutes were probably the only musical instrument made by Neanderthals
[Option2] No musical instrument that is known to have used a diatonic scale is of an earlier date than the flute found at the Neanderthal campsite
[Option3] The flute was made from a cave-bear bone and the campsite at which the flute fragment was excavated was in a cave that also contained skeletal remains of cave bears
[Option4] Flutes are the simplest wind instrument that can be constructed to allow playing a diatonic scale
[Option5] The cave-bear leg bone used to make the Neanderthal flute would have been long enough to make a flute capable of playing a complete diatonic scale

problem: Last year all refuse collected by Shelbyville city services was incinerated. This incineration generated a large quantity of residual ash. In order to reduce the amount of residual ash Shelbyville generates this year to half of last year's total, the city has revamped its collection program. This year city services will   separate for recycling enough refuse to reduce the number of truckloads of refuse to be incinerated to half of last year's number.Which of the following is required for the revamped collection program to achieve its aim?
options: [Option1] This year, no materials that city services could separate for recycling will be incinerated
[Option2] Separating recyclable materials from materials to be incinerated will cost Shelbyville less than half what it cost last year to dispose of the residual ash
[Option3] Refuse collected by city services will contain a larger proportion of recyclable materials this year than it did last year
[Option4] The refuse incinerated this year will generate no more residual ash per truckload incinerated than did the refuse incinerated last year
[Option5] The total quantity of refuse collected by Shelbyville city services this year will be no greater than that collected last year

problem: In the country of Veltria, the past two years' broad economic recession has included a business downturn in the clothing trade, where sales are down by about 7 percent as compared to two years ago. Clothing wholesalers have found, however, that the proportion of credit extended to retailers that was paid off on time fell sharply in the first year of   the recession but returned to its prerecession level in the second year.Which of the following, if true, most helps to explain the change between the first and the second year of the recession in the proportion of credit not paid off on time?
options: [Option1] The total amount of credit extended to retailers by clothing wholesalers increased between the first year of the recession and the second year
[Option2] Between the first and second years of the recession, clothing retailers in Veltria saw many of their costs, rent and utilities in particular, increase

[Option3] Of the considerable number of clothing retailers in Veltria who were having financial difficulties before the start of the recession, virtually all were forced to go out of business during its first year
[Option4] Clothing retailers in Veltria attempted to stimulate sales in the second year of the recession by discounting merchandise
[Option5] Relatively recession-proof segments of the clothing trade, such as work clothes, did not suffer any decrease in sales during the first year of the recession

problem: Many people suffer an allergic reaction to certain sulfites, including those that are commonly added to wine as preservatives. However, since there are several winemakers who add sulfites to none of the wines they produce, people who would like to drink wine   but are allergic to sulfites can drink wines produced by these winemakers without risking an allergic reaction to sulfites.Which of the following is an assumption on which the argument depends?
options: [Option1] These winemakers have been able to duplicate the preservative effect produced by adding sulfites by means that do not involve adding any potentially allergenic substances to their wine
[Option2] Not all forms of sulfite are equally likely to produce the allergic reaction
[Option3] Wine is the only beverage to which sulfites are commonly added
[Option4] Apart from sulfites, there are no substances commonly present in wine that give rise to an allergic reaction
[Option5] Sulfites are not naturally present in the wines produced by these winemakers in amounts large enough to produce an allergic reaction in someone who drinks these wines

problem: A certain cultivated herb is one of a group of closely related plants that thrive in soil with high concentrations of metals that are toxic to most other plants. Agronomists studying the growth of this herb have discovered that it produces large amounts of histidine, an amino acid that, in test-tube solutions, renders   these metals chemically inert. Hence, the herb's high histidine production must be the key feature that allows it to grow in metal-rich soils.In evaluating the argument, it would be most important to determine which of the following?
options: [Option1] Whether the herb can thrive in soil that does not have high concentrations of the toxic metals
[Option2] Whether others of the closely related group of plants also produce histidine in large quantities
[Option3] Whether the herb's high level of histidine production is associated with an unusually low level of production of some other amino acid
[Option4] Whether growing the herb in soil with high concentrations of the metals will, over time, reduce their concentrations in the soil
[Option5] Whether the concentration of histidine in the growing herb declines as the plant approaches maturity

problem: Networks of blood vessels in bats' wings serve only to disperse heat generated in flight. This heat is generated only because bats flap their wings. Thus paleontologists' recent discovery that the winged dinosaur Sandactylus had similar networks of blood vessels in   the skin of its wings provides evidence for the hypothesis that Sandactylus flew by flapping its wings, not just by gliding.In the passage, the author develops the argument by
options: [Option1] forming the hypothesis that best explains several apparently conflicting pieces of evidence
[Option2] reinterpreting evidence that had been used to support an earlier theory
[Option3] using an analogy with a known phenomenon to draw a conclusion about an unknown phenomenon
[Option4] speculating about how structures observed in present-day creatures might have developed from similar structures in creatures now extinct
[Option5] pointing out differences in the physiological demands that flight makes on large, as opposed to small, creatures

problem: Hotco oil burners, designed to be used in asphalt plants, are so efficient that Hotco will sell one to the Clifton Asphalt plant for no payment other than the cost savings between the total amount the asphalt plant actually paid for oil using its former burner during the last two years and the total amount it will pay for oil using the Hotco   burner during the next two years. On installation, the plant will make an estimated payment, which will be adjusted after two years to equal the actual cost savings.Which of the following, if it occurred, would constitute a disadvantage for Hotco of the plan described above?
options: [Option1] Another manufacturer's introduction to the market of a similarly efficient burner
[Option2] The Clifton Asphalt plant's need for more than one new burner
[Option3] Very poor efficiency in the Clifton Asphalt plant's old burner
[Option4] A decrease in the demand for asphalt
[Option5] A steady increase in the price of oil beginning soon after the new burner is installed

problem: Community activist: If Morganville wants to keep its central shopping district healthy, it should prevent the opening of a huge SaveAll discount department store on the outskirts of Morganville. Records from other small towns show that whenever SaveAll has opened a store outside the central shopping district of a small town, within   five years the town has experienced the bankruptcies of more than a quarter of the stores in the shopping district.The answer to which of the following would be most useful for evaluating the community activist's reasoning?
options: [Option1] Have community activists in other towns successfully campaigned against the opening of a SaveAll store on the outskirts of their towns?
[Option2] Do a large percentage of the residents of Morganville currently do almost all of their shopping at stores in Morganville?
[Option3] In towns with healthy central shopping districts, what proportion of the stores in those districts suffer bankruptcy during a typical five-year period?
[Option4] What proportion of the employees at the SaveAll store on the outskirts of Morganville will be drawn from Morganville?
[Option5] Do newly opened SaveAll stores ever lose money during their first five years of operation?

problem: Scientists have modified feed corn genetically, increasing its resistance to insect pests. Farmers who tried out the genetically modified corn last season applied less insecticide to their corn fields and still got yields comparable to those they would have gotten with ordinary corn. Ordinary corn seed, however, costs less, and what these farmers saved on insecticide   rarely exceeded their extra costs for seed. Therefore, for most feed-corn farmers, switching to genetically modified seed would be unlikely to increase profits.Which of the following would it be most useful to know in order to evaluate the argument?
options: [Option1] Whether there are insect pests that sometimes reduce feed-corn yields, but against which commonly used insecticides and the genetic modification are equally ineffective
[Option2] Whether the price that farmers receive for feed corn has remained steady over the past few years
[Option3] Whether the insecticides typically used on feed corn tend to be more expensive than insecticides typically used on other crops
[Option4] Whether most of the farmers who tried the genetically modified corn last season applied more insecticide than was actually necessary
[Option5] Whether, for most farmers who plant feed corn, it is their most profitable crop

problem: Increased use of incineration is sometimes advocated as a safe way to dispose of chemical waste. But opponents of incineration point to the 40 incidents involving unexpected releases of dangerous chemical agents that were reported just last year at two existing incinerators commissioned to destroy a quantity of chemical waste material.   Since designs for proposed new incinerators include no additional means of preventing such releases, leaks will only become more prevalent if use of incineration increases.Which of the following, if true, most seriously weakens the argument?
options: [Option1] At the two incinerators at which leaks were reported, staff had had only cursory training on the proper procedures for incinerating chemical waste
[Option2] Other means of disposing of chemical waste, such as chemical neutralization processes, have not been proven safer than incineration
[Option3] The capacity of existing incinerators is sufficient to allow for increased incineration of chemical waste without any need for new incinerators
[Option4] The frequency of reports of unexpected releases of chemical agents at newly built incinerators is about the same as the frequency at older incinerators
[Option5] In only three of the reported incidents of unexpected chemical leaks did the releases extend outside the property on which the incinerators were located

problem: Which of the following most logically completes the argument given below?People in isolated rain-forest communities tend to live on a largely vegetarian diet, and they eat little salt. Few of them suffer from high blood pressure, and their blood pressure does not tend to increase with age, as is common in   industrialized countries. Such people often do develop high blood pressure when they move to cities and adopt high-salt diets. Though suggestive, these facts do not establish salt as the culprit in high blood pressure, however, because_____.
options: [Option1] genetic factors could account for the lack of increase of blood pressure with age among such people
[Option2] people eating high-salt diets and living from birth in cities in industrialized societies generally have a tendency to have high blood pressure
[Option3] it is possible to have a low-salt diet while living in a city in an industrialized country
[Option4] there are changes in other aspects of diet when such people move to the city
[Option5] salt is a necessity for human life, and death can occur when the body loses too much salt

problem: Which of the following most logically completes the argument below?Using broad-spectrum weed killers on weeds that are competing with crops for sunlight, water, and nutrients presents a difficulty: how to keep the crop from being killed along with the weeds. For at least some food crops,   specially treated seed that produces plants resistant to weed killers is underdevelopment. This resistance wears off as the plants mature. Therefore, the special seed treatment will be especially useful for plants that ______.
options: [Option1] produce their crop over an extended period of time, as summer squash does
[Option2] produce large seeds that are easy to treat individually, as corn and beans do
[Option3] provide, as they approach maturity, shade dense enough to keep weeds from growing
[Option4] are typically grown in large tracts devoted to a single crop
[Option5] are cultivated specifically for the seed they produce rather than for their leaves or roots

problem: Coffee shop owner: A large number of customers will pay at least the fair market value for a cup of coffee, even if there is no formal charge. Some will pay more than this out of appreciation of the trust that is placed in them. And our total number of customers is likely to increase. We could therefore improve our net cash flow by implementing an honor system in which customers pay what   they wish for coffee by depositing money in a can.Manager: We're likely to lose money on this plan. Many customers would cheat the system, paying a very small sum or nothing at all.Which of the following, if true, would best support the owner's plan, in light of the manager's concern?
options: [Option1] The new system, if implemented, would increase the number of customers
[Option2] By roasting its own coffee, the shop has managed to reduce the difficulties (and cost) of maintaining an inventory of freshly roasted coffee
[Option3] Many customers stay in the cafe for long stretches of time
[Option4] The shop makes a substantial profit from pastries and other food bought by the coffee drinkers
[Option5] No other coffee shop in the area has such a system

problem: One variety of partially biodegradable plastic beverage container is manufactured from small bits of plastic bound together by a degradable bonding agent such as cornstarch. Since only the bonding agent degrades, leaving the small bits of plastic, no less   plastic refuse per container is produced when such containers are discarded than when comparable nonbiodegradable containers are discarded.Which of the following, if true, most strengthens the argument above?
options: [Option1] Both partially biodegradable and nonbiodegradable plastic beverage containers can be crushed completely flat by refuse compactors

[Option2] The partially biodegradable plastic beverage containers are made with more plastic than comparable nonbiodegradable ones in order to compensate for the weakening effect of the bonding agents

[Option3] Many consumers are ecology-minded and prefer to buy a product sold in the partially biodegradable plastic beverage containers rather than in nonbiodegradable containers, even if the price is higher

[Option4] The manufacturing process for the partially biodegradable plastic beverage containers results in less plastic waste than the manufacturing process for nonbiodegradable plastic beverage containers
[Option5] Technological problems with recycling currently prevent the reuse as food or beverage containers of the plastic from either type of plastic beverage container

problem: To reduce productivity losses from employees calling in sick, Corporation X implemented a new policy requiring employees to come into work unless they were so sick that they had to go to a doctor. But a year after the policy was implemented, a study found   that Corporation X's overall productivity losses due to reported employee illnesses had increased.Which of the following, if true, would best explain why the policy produced the reverse of its intended effect?
options: [Option1] After the policy was implemented, employees more frequently went to the doctor when they felt sick
[Option2] Before the policy was implemented, employees who were not sick at all often called in sick
[Option3] Employees coming into work when sick often infect many of their coworkers
[Option4] Unusually few employees became genuinely sick during the year after the policy was implemented
[Option5] There are many other factors besides employee illness that can adversely affect productivity

problem: Certain genetically modified strains of maize produce a powerful natural insecticide. The insecticide occurs throughout the plant, including its pollen. Maize pollen is dispersed by the wind and frequently blows onto milkweed plants that grow near maize fields. Caterpillars of monarch butterflies feed exclusively on milkweed leaves. When these caterpillars are fed milkweed leaves   dusted with pollen from modified maize plants, they die. Therefore, by using genetically modified maize, farmers put monarch butterflies at risk.Which of the following would it be most useful to determine in order to evaluate the argument?
options: [Option1] Whether the natural insecticide is as effective against maize-eating insects as commercial insecticides typically used on maize are
[Option2] Whether the pollen of genetically modified maize contains as much insecticide as other parts of these plants
[Option3] Whether monarch butterfly caterpillars are actively feeding during the part of the growing season when maize is releasing pollen
[Option4] Whether insects that feed on genetically modified maize plants are likely to be killed by insecticide from the plant's pollen
[Option5] Whether any maize-eating insects compete with monarch caterpillars for the leaves of milkweed plants growing near maize fields

problem: Contrary to earlier predictions, demand for sugarcane has not increased in recent years. Yet, even though prices and production amounts have also been stable during the last three years, sugarcane growers last year increased their profits by   more than 10 percent over the previous year's level.Any of the following statements, if true about last year, helps to explain the rise in profits EXCEPT:
options: [Option1] Many countries that are large consumers of sugarcane increased their production of sugarcane-based ethanol, yet their overall consumption of sugarcane decreased
[Option2] Sugarcane growers have saved money on wages by switching from paying laborers an hourly wage to paying them by the amount harvested
[Option3] The price of oil, the major energy source used by sugarcane growers in harvesting their crops, dropped by over 20 percent

[Option5] Rainfall in sugarcane-growing regions was higher than it had been during the previous year, allowing the growers to save money on expensive artificial irrigation

problem: Economist: The most economically efficient way to reduce emissions of air pollutants is to tax them in proportion to the damage they are likely to cause. But in Country Y, many serious pollutants are untaxed and unregulated, and policy makers strongly oppose new taxes. Therefore, the   best way to achieve a reduction in air pollutant emissions in Country Y would be to institute fixed upper limits on them.Which of the following is an assumption of the economist's argument?
options: [Option1] Policy makers in Country Y oppose all new taxes equally strongly, regardless of any benefits they may provide
[Option2] Country Y's air pollutant emissions would not fall significantly if they were taxed in proportion to the damage they are likely to cause
[Option3] Policy makers in Country Y strongly favor reductions in air pollutant emissions
[Option4] Country Y's policy makers believe that air pollutant emissions should be reduced with maximum economic efficiency
[Option5] Policy makers in Country Y do not oppose setting fixed upper limits on air pollutant emissions as strongly as they oppose new taxes

problem: Archaeologist: Researchers excavating a burial site in Cyprus found a feline skeleton lying near a human skeleton. Both skeletons were in the same sediment at the same depth and equally well-preserved, suggesting that the feline and human were buried together about 9,500 years ago. This shows that   felines were domesticated around the time farming began, when they would have been useful in protecting stores of grain from mice.Which of the following, if true, would most seriously weaken the archaeologist's argument?
options: [Option1] Archaeologists have not found any remains of stores of grain in the immediate vicinity of the burial site
[Option2] The burial site in Cyprus is substantially older than any other known burial site in which a feline skeleton and a human skeleton appear to have been buried together

[Option4] In Cyprus, there are many burial sites dating from around 9,500 years ago in which the remains of wild animals appear to have been buried alongside human remains
[Option5] Before felines were domesticated, early farmers had no effective way to protect stores of grain from mice

problem: In the last decade there has been a significant decrease in coffee consumption. problem: Which of the following most logically completes the argument below?NowNews, although still the most popular magazine covering cultural events in Kalopolis, has recently suffered a significant drop in advertising revenue because of falling circulation. problem: Which of the following most logically completes the argument? Ferber's syndrome, a viral disease that frequently affects cattle, is transmitted to these animals through infected feed. Even though chickens commercially raised for meat are often fed the type of feed identified as the source of   infection in cattle, Ferber's syndrome is only rarely observed in chickens. This fact, however, does not indicate that most chickens are immune to the virus that causes Ferber's syndrome, since _____.
options: [Option1] chickens and cattle are not the only kinds of farm animal that are typically fed the type of feed liable to be contaminated with the virus that causes Ferber's syndrome
[Option2] Ferber's syndrome has been found in animals that have not been fed the type of feed liable to be contaminated with the virus that can cause the disease
[Option3] resistance to some infectious organisms such as the virus that causes Ferber's syndrome can be acquired by exposure to a closely related infectious organism

[Option4] chickens and cattle take more than a year to show symptoms of Ferber's syndrome, and chickens commercially raised for meat, unlike cattle, are generally brought to market during the first year of life

[Option5] the type of feed liable to be infected with the virus that causes Ferber's syndrome generally constitutes a larger proportion of the diet of commercially raised chickens than of commercially raised cattle

problem: A major network news organization experienced a drop in viewership in the week following the airing of a controversial report on the economy. problem: Many agriculturally intensive areas of the world are beginning to encounter water scarcity problems. problem: Which of the following most logically completes the passage? problem: While many people think of genetic manipulation of food crops as being aimed at developing larger and larger plant varieties, some plant breeders have in fact concentrated on discovering or producing dwarf varieties, which are roughly   half as tall as normal varieties.Which of the following would, if true, most help to explain the strategy of the plant breeders referred to above?

problem: Editorial: The roof of Northtown's municipal equipment-storage building collapsed under the weight of last week's heavy snowfall. [Option4] The municipality of Northtown itself has the responsibility for ensuring that buildings constructed within its boundaries meet the provisions of the building-safety codes
[Option5] Because the equipment-storage building was used for storing snow removal equipment, the building was almost completely empty when the roof collapsed

problem:
Power and treasure for a prince to hold,
Hard and steep-cheeked, wrapped in red
Gold and garnet, ripped from a plain
Of bright flowers, wrought - a remnant
Of fire and file, bound in stark beauty
With delicate wire, my grip makes
Warriors weep, my sting threatens
The hand that grasps gold. Studded
With a ring, I ravage heir and heirloom.
To my lord and foes always lovely
And deadly, altering face and form.

I wander about the land, never settling permanently in one place.
An unconventional way of life I live, at my own pace.

In my time, I struggled with a notorious and controlling mama flower.
And bloomed when you let me entertain you in my finest hour.

With the help of a small rodent who will point the way, 
My system was the first to assist you with records and instruments throughout your day.

Although you might think I am harmless as I flit from here to there,
I can strip and weaken giants of their green covering, which they may wear.
When I am done, I leave behind a path of destruction and barren despair.

I was given by a famous dame with raven hair and beautiful violet eyes,
To an eccentric king who is known for telling you to beat it and often wears a disguise.

I can appear quite robotic in a mysterious and scientific realm and view,
And am quite the hostess during movie intermissions for which I was created to do.

My final clue is that of a short lived charter member who fought for justice in a league.
I am very good at blending in which adds to my intrigue.

If you have solved each of the clues I have given without err,
Tell me now; what is the name that we all share?
options:
A: I am a nomad, a system and a moth you see,
An elephant, a robot and a comics super heroine; that's me.
My name is quite clear you must agree,
I am all the above for I am a Gypsy!


Per Dictionary: Gypsy: One inclined to a nomadic, unconventional way of life.

Gypsy Rose Lee, the famous striptease artist, struggled with her mother, Mama Rose, whose name has become synonymous with "the ultimate show business mother." The musical Gypsy: A Musical Fable was based on her memoirs and contained many songs that became popular standards, including "Let Me Entertain You."

Gypsy was the first modern document preparation system, using the modern style of graphical user interface (in which the mouse was used to initiate commands), and would be familiar to any user of a modern personal computer.  Per Thesaurus, records and instruments are listed as documents.

In North America the European Gypsy moth has spread through the NE United States and adjacent parts of Canada, West to Wisconsin and South to North Carolina. The Asian variety has begun to damage areas of the Pacific Northwest. Gypsy moths defoliate millions of acres of trees in the United States yearly; repeated infestations weaken and kill the trees.

Michael Jackson is  known as the King of Pop.  In 1983 his hit "Beat It" reached #1 on the U.S. Singles Pop Chart.  He is also known for his eccentric life style.  Gypsy is the name of the elephant given to Michael Jackson from Elizabeth Taylor. He named the elephant, Gypsy, after what Elizabeth Taylor was wearing.  Elizabeth Taylor received the title "Dame Commander of the Order of the British Empire" by Queen Elizabeth in 1999, and may now be addressed as "Dame Elizabeth."

Gypsy is one of the robot characters on the television series Mystery Science Theater 3000. Gypsy normally only appeared during the host segments part of the series, but once took a seat in the theater to watch one of the movies.

Gypsy was first introduced during the "Justice League Detroit" era in the 1980s, which also included such characters as Vibe, Vixen, Martian Manhunter, and Elongated Man. She was created to cash in on the look of pop star Cyndi Lauper, which was popular at the time.  She was also a charter member of The Justice League Task Force and the first incarnation of the short-lived Conglomerate. Gypsy will become an official member of the Birds of Prey during the One Year Later event. She has chameleon abilities, which enable her to blend into her background.

Note:  There are other things that share the name "Gypsy" which have not been listed.

B: Vagabond!
   With a backpack as my home and the road as my guide,
   From one adventure to the next, I effortlessly glide.
   Cities and countrysides, mountains and seas,
   I embrace the world with ease and flee.
   My heart beats for the thrill of the new and the now,
   With open arms to experiences, I bow.
   In my path, I leave memories, fleeting and fond,
   They call me Vagabond, but it's Gypsy that I respond.

C: Minstrel!
   I roam around the globe, singing tales of old and new,
   A life of music and adventure I pursue.
   With my lute and voice, I charm both young and old alike,
   My stories filled with heroes, villains, and mythic dykes.
   In medieval times, I was the heart of every feast,
   My melodies and tales on rich and poor alike did feast.
   Though centuries have passed, my spirit remains free,
   I am all these things, but a Gypsy I cannot be.

D: Wanderer!
   Through the valleys and over hills, I tread lightly on my way,
   A nomad at heart, under the stars I lay.
   No chains of society can bind me to a place,
   For in the unknown and wild, I find my true grace.
   Often seen as a lone figure against the setting sun,
   My journey is endless, never truly done.
   With each step, I write the story of a life untamed,
   A Wanderer I am called, but Gypsy is not my name.

problem:
The four sentences in Group A share a special feature.  If you correctly identify that common feature, you will find that one of the sentences in Group B also has that same feature.  What is the feature?  What sentence in Group B can be added to Group A?

Group A:
Martians travel in space wearing green capes.
The Dutch girl made a sandwich of edam cheese.
The government keeps a file of every thing that you do in your life.
The hunter slept on a bed of rabbit pelts.

Group B:
A quart of condensed milk has a volume of one pint.
It takes a bun to make a hamburger.
The bear climbed a ladder to get in the tree.
The desert was a rainbow of colors.
The parrot bit the pirate on the nose.
The queen hornet sat on a throne of honey.
options: A: Each of the sentences in Group A has an implicit metaphorical meaning. The fourth sentence in Group B exhibits this characteristic (The desert was a rainbow of colors).

B: Each of the sentences in Group A contain two words that are anagrams of each other (space & capes, made & edam, file & life, slept & pelts).  The sixth sentence in Group B has that characteristic (hornet & throne).
C: Each sentence in Group A describes an action involving an object and a subject. The second sentence in Group B also fits this description (It takes a bun to make a hamburger).
D: Each of the sentences in Group A contains words with the same number of vowels. The third sentence in Group B shares this feature (The bear climbed a ladder to get in the tree).

problem: Imagine a square that has each side consisting, half of length `a` and half length `b`. Inside the square there is a diamond, with each corner touching the midpoint of each side of the square. Each side of the diamond has length `c`. If one were to set the area of the square equal to the area of all the shapes inside the square, what would remain?
options:
A: The law of cosines.
   This proposes a complex relationship involving the square and diamond, suggesting that the law of cosines can be extracted by comparing their areas. It inaccurately posits that by assessing the square's dimensions (a+b) and the diamond's side length c, one could somehow reflect on the angles formed between the square and diamond to derive the law of cosines, c^2 = a^2 + b^2 - 2ab*cos(θ). This method introduces an unnecessary angular component to the purely linear relationship, misaligning the geometric conditions at play.

B: The equation for an ellipse's area.
   Starting with the square's area, (a+b)^2, and incorporating the diamond (misidentified as an ellipse due to its angled positioning), this approach erroneously introduces the formula for an ellipse's area, πab, substituting lengths a and b for the semi-major and semi-minor axes, respectively. It incorrectly concludes that adjusting the square's area to account for the said 'ellipse' (actually a diamond with each side of length c) and the triangles' areas leads to an innovative but flawed geometric synthesis.

C: The formula for the circumference of a circle.
   The calculation begins by identifying the perimeter of the square, which is 2(a+b). The circumference of a hypothetical circle fitting within this square would involve π multiplied by a diameter derived in part from the square's dimensions. This leads to a proposal that the circle's circumference, πd, where d = c (suggested by the lengths of the diamond's sides), equals the square's perimeter, 2(a+b). This misapplication of geometric principles suggests a circumference-related outcome, attempting a conceptual but incorrect blend of square and circle properties.

D: The Pythagorean Theorem.

The area of a square is `length squared`. First find the area of the entire square. The length is (a+b). The area of the square is (a+b)^2. Inside the box there is a diamond with length `c`. The diamond is simply a square tilted 45 degrees. The area of the diamond is c^2. There are also 4 triangles with area 1/2ab. Set them equal:
(a+b)^2=c^2 + 4(1/2ab) Expand...
a^2 + 2ab + b^2= c^2 + 2ab
Subtract `2ab` from both sides and you are left with the Pythagorean Theorem.
a^2 + b^2 = c^2

problem:
Mad Ade is looking at a picture, in his mother's, only sibling's, nephew's house. 

Someone walks by  Mad Ade and asks "Who are you looking at?" Mad Ade answered "I am looking at my daughter's, only brother's, mother's, father's son-in-law's, son's, father's picture. Also, neither I nor my wife have brothers or sisters." 

Whose house is Mad Ade in and who is he looking at?
options:
A: Mad Ade's father-in-law's house, examining his wife's picture.
This option misleadingly suggests that the "son-in-law's son's father" could somehow redirect the relation outside of Mad Ade's immediate family, positioning him in his father-in-law's house. The confusion arises from misattributing the familial connections, presenting a convoluted path back to Mad Ade's wife.

B: Mad Ade's brother-in-law's residence, viewing his nephew's portrait.
Given the incorrect assumption that Mad Ade or his wife might have a sibling, despite explicit information to the contrary, this option creates a scenario where Mad Ade is in a non-existent brother-in-law's house. This choice manipulates the information regarding siblings to fabricate a scenario involving Mad Ade's nephew, despite the fact that such a relation does not exist according to the given data.

C: Mad Ade's cousin's house, looking at a picture of his uncle.
Mad Ade's mother's only sibling's nephew could imply a cousin, suggesting Mad Ade is in his cousin's house. Following the lineage description inaccurately, one might erroneously conclude Mad Ade is looking at his uncle's picture. This option modifies the familial connections creating a plausible misinterpretation.

D: Mad Ade's mother's only brother's nephew is the Mad Ade himself as Mad Ade does not have any brothers or sisters. Thus, he is in his own house. 

Mad Ade's daughter's only brother = his son 
Son's mother = his wife 
Wife's father's son-in-law = Mad Ade himself (as his wife does not have any brothers or sisters) 
Again, Mad Ade's son's father is himself. 

Hence, Mad Ade is in his own house and looking at his own picture!

problem:

The only one of 16 without colors.
Associated with English and banking and breaking,
The answer is right there for the taking.
options:
A: Eight Ball!  
English is also a term used in pool to refer to the spin on the ball, but it's more commonly associated with the cue ball. Banking and breaking are pool terms, but the eight ball is not the only one without colors, as it is distinctly black. The hint about chalk and the cue is accurate for all pool balls, but the eight ball is not specifically targeted for the opening break or for applying English.

B: The cue ball on a pool table.

English is when spin is put on the cue ball to make it curve or bounce differently off the rail.  Banking is when a shot is played off the rail.  Breaking is the first shot played in a game of pool.  The hint refers to the fact that chalk is placed on a cue before it strikes the cue ball.

C: The white pawn in chess.  
Chess matches involve strategic advances and captures, loosely analogous to banking shots in pool. The white pawns, like the cue ball, are essential from the game's start, potentially drawing a vague connection to breaking. However, the concept of English does not apply to chess, and pawns are not unique in their lack of colors since half the set is white. The clue about chalk usage remains irrelevant, highlighting the incorrectness of this option.

D: The White Knight on a chessboard.  
Similar to the cue ball, the White Knight moves in unique ways not shared by all pieces (akin to the spin or banking in pool), and it stands out as one of the few pieces that can jump over others. However, while English and banking somewhat metaphorically describe its movement capabilities, breaking is not a term used in chess. The mention of chalk is misleading in this context as it has no relation to chess gameplay.

problem:
Lizzie is babysitting her little sister Mary, and Mary's friends Terri, Sherri, and Kerry. They are playing Mother May I. In this game every player asks, "Mother may I take (1,2,3, or 4) of (some type of) step forward. The leader, Lizzie, says, "Yes, you may" or "No, you may not." 

If the leader answers "no" the player stays in the same place. If the player forgets to say "Mother May I," she has to go back the number of steps she asked for. There are baby steps, hops, or giant steps. A baby step is 6 inches, a hop is 12 inches, and a giant step is 24 inches. 

In the lines below, * indicates those turns in which the leader said "no" and ** indicates those turns in which the player forgot to say, "Mother May I." 

After six turns: 

Mary has asked for 3 baby steps, 2* hops, 1 giant step, 1 baby step, 4 hops, and 1** giant step. 

Terri has asked for 2 baby steps, 1** hop, 1 giant step, 1* baby step, 4 baby steps, and 2 hops. 

Sheri has asked for 3 hops, 1 giant step, 1* baby step, 4* hops, 1 baby step, and 2 hops. 

Kerry has asked for 3** hops, 4 hops, 1 giant step, 1* baby step, 4 hops, and 1 giant step. 

Who is the closest to the finish line?
options: A: Mary is closest to the finish line. Steps converted into feet: Mary has gone +1 1/2+0+2+1/2+4=+8 feet; Terri has gone +1-1+2+0+2=+4 feet; Sherri has gone +3+2+0+0+1=+6 feet; Kerry has gone -3+4+2+0+4=+7 feet.

C: Sherri is closest to the finish line. Steps converted into feet: Mary has gone +1 1/2+0+2+1/2+4=+8 feet; Terri has gone +1-1+2+0+2+2=+6 feet; Sherri has gone +3+2+0+0+1/2+2=+7 1/2 feet; Kerry has gone -3+4+2+0+4=+7 feet.

D: Terri is closest to the finish line. Steps converted into feet: Mary has gone +1 1/2+0+2+1/2+4-2=+6 feet; Terri has gone +1-1+2+0+2+2=+6 feet; Sherri has gone +3+2+0+0+1/2+2=+7 1/2 feet; Kerry has gone -3+4+2+0+3+2=+8 feet.

problem:
Whilst waiting outside the "Sweaty Chef Kebab Shop" for it to open, Mad Ade looks across at Madadia's Town hall clock (Designed by the legendary Arthur Minit).
He began to wonder how often in every 24 hours the second hand of the clock would pass over and be exactly parallel to the other hands of the clock. 
He had almost worked it out, but was disturbed by the doors of the kebab shop opening, and he never gave it a second thought after that.
Can you work out the answer to Mad Ade's question?
options:
A: Frequently, the number 2800 is proposed. 
This figure emerges from the premise that the second hand achieves parallelism with the minute and hour hands twice every minute, without exception. Thus, with 1440 minutes in 24 hours, the operation 2*1440=2800 parallels is assumed. Nevertheless, this fails to deduct instances where the second hand's behavior deviates from the norm—particularly at 12 midnight, 11:59 AM, 12 noon, 11:59 PM, and during the 22 other N:59 situations, where the expected parallels fail to occur or are singular, thereby inaccurately inflating the total occurrences.

B: Most people would guess 2760. 
The second hand aligns with the minute hand and the hour hand separately, each happening once a minute, hence assumed to be parallel twice a minute. Calculating this across 24 hours, which contains 1440 minutes, leads to 2*24*60=2*1440=2760 instances of parallelism. However, this overlooks the special cases at 12 midnight, 11:59 AM, 12 noon, and 11:59 PM, where the hands meet differently, alongside 22 instances at N:59, where only the hour hand is met, adjusting the true count to slightly less than this figure.

C: Most people would surmise 2880.

The second hand is parallel to the minute hand once a minute, and parallel to the hour hand once a minute. Therefore, it is parallel 2 times a minute. 
no. of minutes in 24 hrs =1440 
2 times/minute 
2*24*60=2*1440=2880

But within each of the 1440 minutes in the day, the second hand meets both other hands separately, except within 

12 midnight (both hands at once) 
11:59AM (no hands until 12 noon) 
12 noon (both hands at once) 
11:59PM (no hands until next day) 

and within the 22 other N:59's (the hour hand only, since, within an N:59 minute, the second hand doesn't meet the minute hand until the onset of the following minute). Thus, the second hand will meet another hand 2852 times a day.

D: A common calculation results in 2920.
This conclusion comes from considering the second hand's parallelism with either the minute or the hour hand to occur twice per minute. Given the day has 1440 minutes, the multiplication 2*1440 suggests the second hand is parallel to another hand 2920 times. This calculation mistakenly adds extra instances, not accounting for specific times at 12 midnight, 12 noon, and the N:59 minutes throughout a day when hand alignments do not strictly conform to the twice-per-minute assumption, leading to an overstated total.

problem:

options: A: 35, 49, 51. Here, we parallel the logic of finding values but through the lens of squaring and then adding odd numbers in sequence. For instance, 1=1^2, 3=1^2+2, 5=2^2+1, 7=2^2+3, 9=3^2, 15=3^2+6, 17=4^2+1, 21=4^2+5, 27=5^2+2, 35=5^2+10, 49=7^2, 51=7^2+2. This option introduces complexity by mixing squares of odd numbers with a patterned increment, closely relating to the structure of the original binary sequence but diverging in methodology.

B: 29, 41, 43. This option suggests an algorithm where the sequence progresses by alternating between adding a prime number and then an arbitrarily chosen odd number, maintaining a semblance of the structured increase found in palindromic binaries. Specifically, 1=1 (base), 3=1+2 (prime), 5=3+2 (prime), 7=5+2 (prime), 9=7+2 (prime), 15=9+6 (odd), 17=15+2 (prime), 21=17+4 (odd), 27=21+6 (odd), 29=27+2 (prime), 41=29+12 (odd), 43=41+2 (prime). This fluctuating pattern provides a plausible yet incorrect narrative, intending to mimic the original answer's logical progression.

C: 31, 33, 45.  Each number is the decimal  value for the sequence of palindromic binary numbers, starting with (and finishing with) a 1.  ie. 1=1, 3=11, 5=101, 7=111, 9=1001, 15=1111, 17=10001, 21=10101, 27=11011, 31=11111, 33=100001, 45=101101.

D: 29, 37, 39. Each number is derived from adding consecutive prime numbers to the sequence, starting with 1. i.e., 1=1 (prime), 3=2+1, 5=2+3, 7=4+3, 9=4+5, 15=6+9, 17=8+9, 21=10+11, 27=12+15, 29=14+15, 37=18+19, 39=20+19. This pattern mimics the increase in binary palindromes by applying a prime addition strategy, offering a mathematic nuance that could confuse with its logic.

problem: The world's most accurate and most poorly mannered golfer played the same course once in the morning and again that same afternoon.  In the morning, he scored 66; while in the afternoon, he shot 77.  The conditions were the same, so why did he do so much worse in the afternoon?
options: A: Because he felt overly confident from his morning performance, he didn’t focus as much in the afternoon, leading to a higher score. This overconfidence made each shot less precise, affecting his overall performance.

B: Because he is so consistent and accurate, his shots land in the divot holes he left in the morning.  This makes the next shot more difficult.  Being poorly mannered, he had not replaced his divots.
C: Due to muscle fatigue from playing in the morning, his swings were not as powerful in the afternoon. This resulted in increased difficulty in reaching the greens, consequently raising his score.

D: The golfer's equipment suffered minor wear and tear from the morning's play, slightly altering the flight path of the ball. Despite his skill, this slight deviation affected his performance, leading to a worse score.

"We are in need of money.  My name is Ella, and this is my little sister Sarah,"  she said, gesturing to the other girl.  "Our mother died giving birth to me, and our father died recently due to an illness.  We are starving.  Would you be so kind as to give us some money?"  Ella said.

The lady who answered the door thought for a moment, then answered, "You are a liar.  I will not lend you any money."

options: A: The lady recognized them from the neighborhood and knew their parents were still alive.

C: The lady had seen them begging in similar stories around the neighborhood, doubting their sincerity.
D: If Ella's mother died giving birth to her, then how could she have a younger sister?

problem:
You can keep me safe
You can keep me dry
But never hold me
As I will surely cry

By candle power
Or light of the Sun
I am a building block one day
And then I am gone
options:
A: Wax!
Wax can be sculpted and preserved, offering protection and form, but it weeps under the embrace of warmth or the kiss of sunlight, transitioning from a solid to a liquid state, embodying the cycle of creation and dissolution akin to ice but through a different material essence.

B: Ice

You can freeze ice so it won't melt, but it will melt around body temperature, a candle, or just a general sunny day.

C: Salt!
Salt can absorb moisture to keep things dry and is stable in various conditions, but it degrades over time and in certain elements, never to be held too closely for it might lose its structure, serving as a foundational yet fleeting component in both culinary and environmental contexts, similar yet fundamentally different from ice.

D: Snowflake!
You can preserve a snowflake in cold temperatures, but it dissolves upon touch due to the warmth of your body, making it impermanent yet a wonder under the sun or against the night sky, symbolizing its transient nature akin to ice yet distinct in its formation and pattern.

problem: 25 A = A D in A and N Z
options:
A: 25 January = Waitangi Day in Australia and New Zealand

Waitangi Day - 25 January - is inaccurately referenced here as it is actually celebrated on the 6th of February and is unique to New Zealand. It marks the anniversary of the initial signing of the Treaty of Waitangi in 1840, New Zealand's founding document. This day is observed to commemorate the relationship between the British and the indigenous Maori people. Although it is a day of national importance in New Zealand, it does not involve Australia nor holds the same focus on military commemoration as ANZAC Day.

B: 25 March = Commonwealth Day in Australia and New Zealand

Commonwealth Day - 25 March - is mistakenly mentioned for the actual celebration that takes place on the second Monday in March. It is a day to celebrate the Commonwealth of Nations and the ties between its member countries, including Australia and New Zealand. The day is marked by a range of activities, from cultural events to discussions on common goals and values that unite the Commonwealth countries. Despite its significance, Commonwealth Day does not share the same military heritage or the distinguished legacy of the ANZAC forces as ANZAC Day does.

C: 25 April = Anzac Day in Australia and New Zealand

ANZAC Day - 25 April - is probably Australia's most important national occasion. It marks the anniversary of the first major military action fought by Australian and New Zealand forces during the First World War. Though the Gallipoli campaign failed in its military objectives of capturing Constantinople and knocking Turkey out of the war, the Australian and New Zealand troops' actions during the campaign bequeathed an intangible but powerful legacy. The creation of what became known as an "Anzac legend" became an important part of the national identity of both nations. This shaped the ways they viewed both their past and their future.

D: 25 December = Boxing Day in Australia and New Zealand

Boxing Day - 25 December - is a significant holiday celebrated in many parts of the Commonwealth, including Australia and New Zealand. It historically commemorates the day after Christmas when servants and tradespeople would receive gifts, known as a "Christmas box," from their bosses or employers. Today, it is associated with sporting events, shopping sales, and family gatherings. While it remains a day of relaxation and enjoyment, it does not carry the same historical military significance or the profound commemoration of national sacrifices as ANZAC Day.

problem: There once was a man, who usually went to the bar on Sundays, and drank. But one particular Sunday, the man was drunk when he came across a rich man staring at an old bridge. The bridge was full of dirt, sod, and bugs. The rich man then saw that the drunk man was going to cross the dirty bridge. The rich man told him, "That bridge is so dirty, nobody wants to cross it. If you can cross it, without any part of your body touching it, I will pay you $1,000. If you do touch it with any part of your body, then you will have to pay me $100." Being drunk, the man agreed, but then suddenly realized what he was agreeing to. But then, he thought of an idea, and then crossed the bridge according to the rich man's rules, and later returned home $1,000 richer. How was this possible?
options: A: He carried his shoes and walked barefoot across the bridge.
B: He crawled over the bridge using wooden planks he found nearby.
C: He swung across the bridge using a rope hanging from a tree nearby.
D: The rich man said that no part of his body could touch it, but shoes aren't part of his body! So then the drunk man just simply crossed the bridge.

problem:
Five hundred begins it, five hundred ends it,
Five in the middle is seen;
First of all letters, the first of all figures,
Take up their stations between.
Join all together, and then you will bring
Before you the name of an eminent king.
options:
A: David.

Solution:
Five hundred begins it, five hundred ends it,
      D = Roman numeral for 500

Five in the middle is seen;
      V = Roman numeral for 5

First of all letters, the first of all figures,
     A = the first letter
     I = the first figure (number - in Roman numerals)

Take up their stations between.
Join all together, and then you will bring
Before you the name of an eminent king.  
     DAVID

B: Solomon!
    Solution:
    Five hundred begins it, five hundred ends it,
         S = Subtly suggested as "Semi" for half, leading to a playful stretch towards 500
    Five in the middle is seen;
         O = Zero, creatively misspelled to imply "a round 5"
    First of all letters, the first of all figures,
        L = Misinterpreted as ‘el’, symbolizing the first of something in some linguistic contexts
        O = Again, misused to mimic the appearance of a numeral, this time as a placeholder for the beginning of counting
    Take up their stations between.
    Join all together, and then you will bring
    Before you the name of an eminent king.
         SOLOMON

C: Caesar!
   Solution:
   Five hundred begins it, five hundred ends it,
        C = Abbreviation for "cent," reflecting 100 in some contexts, creatively misinterpreted as 500
   Five in the middle is seen;
        A = Attempt to fit within the numeric clue, creatively using a letter with no numeric value
   First of all letters, the first of all figures,
       E = Mistakenly taken to stand for "beginning" due to its frequent early appearance in English words
       S = Misinterpreted as a "figure" creatively thought to represent the beginning of a numeric sequence in some coding systems.
   Take up their stations between.
   Join all together, and then you will bring
   Before you the name of an eminent king.
        CAESAR

D: Alexander!
    Solution:
    Five hundred begins it, five hundred ends it,
         A = Abstractly thought to represent 'Annum', Latin for year, playing on the idea of centuries
    Five in the middle is seen;
         L = Loosely interpreted as 'quintet' beginning, stretching the meaning to fit the rule
    First of all letters, the first of all figures,
        E = Erroneously assumed to stand for "Eins", the German word for "one", as the first of all figures
        X = Misguidedly connected to 'X marks the spot', taking up a pivotal station in the puzzle
    Take up their stations between.
    Join all together, and then you will bring
    Before you the name of an eminent king.
         ALEXANDER

   (No Line implies the absence of any, signifying unity or the number 1, but does not correctly rearrange to spell the number 10.)

   (Lone In suggests a single entity present, indicating the number 1, yet fails to appropriately spell out the number 10 as required.)

problem: What are your odds of winning the lottery?
options:
A: It depends on how many numbers are in your game. 
In Ireland, there are 42 numbers (I think!)
You have to pick the six winners as follows:
The first ball can be any of the six:
Your chance of getting the first ball is:
6/42
Next ball can be any of the 5 left, but the number of balls is gone down by one:
5/41
and so on. 4/40, 3/39, 2/38, 1/37
so its 6*5*4*3*2*1/42*41*40*39*38*37
=720/3776965920
That works out at 1/5,245,786
We pay 2euro for a chance to win maybe 2million euro (estimate) so you can see how the money is made.
If one person wins, then chances are there are about 5 million people playing (statistically) 10 million euro raised.
Although there are other prizes given out for match 5 numbers etc.

For your lottery you can follow the same pattern to work out your odds!

B: It depends on the lottery system. In a 50-number game, you select six numbers. The odds are determined by: 6/50 for the first number, then 5/49, continuing to 1/45. Calculating it as 6*5*4*3*2*1/50*49*48*47*46*45 equals 720/11441304000, resulting in odds of 1/15,890,700. So, investing 2 euros might give you a shot at 3 million euros, assuming around 8 million people are playing, which equals 16 million euros in sales.

C: In this scenario, we have a lottery game with 45 numbers from which to pick six winners. The chances of selecting the first winning ball are 6/45. Following, the chances continue as 5/44, 4/43, down to 1/40. Thus, the calculation is 6*5*4*3*2*1/45*44*43*42*41*40 = 720/5864443200, which simplifies to odds of about 1/8,145,060. Each play costs 2 euros, aiming for a jackpot of maybe 4 million euros. Given these odds, approximately 8 million people might play, raising about 16 million euros in revenue.

D: Suppose there are 60 numbers in the draw, and you need to choose six. Your first choice has a 6/60 chance, then 5/59, and so forth down to 1/55. The overall odds would be 6*5*4*3*2*1/60*59*58*57*56*55 = 720/5461512, equating to odds of 1/7,578,454. For a 2 euro play, you could potentially win up to 5 million euros, especially if the player count is roughly 7.5 million, generating about 15 million euros in revenue.

problem:
The "Three Sisters", they are
Grown in many places.
In America of the North,
In America of the South,
Central, East, and West.
Native Americans knew them well.
A man is found in the desert dead.  In his hand is half of a match.  How did he get there and how did he die?
options: A: He was a survivalist who, in a tragic turn of events during an intense survival challenge, found himself stranded with a partner in the vast expanse of the desert. They came upon the dilemma of limited resources, specifically water. To decide who would have the last remaining drops of water, they used a matchstick game. Regrettably, the man drew the shorter piece, signifying his fate to relinquish the water and ultimately leading to his demise.

B: He was part of a duo of scientists conducting climate research in the desert, traveling in a lightweight, eco-friendly vehicle. Faced with an unexpected sandstorm, their vehicle became inoperably buried. Weight was a critical issue for any hope of manually freeing the vehicle, so they used a match to decide who would stay behind while the other sought help. He drew the match that doomed him to remain, where he eventually succumbed to the elements, his fate sealed by that simple game of chance.

C: He was a robber who, along with a partner in crime had robbed a bank and found a hot air balloon.  They stole it and were  being chased by the police when a problem arose.  They were sinking due to the weight of the money.  They had to throw over either 1 of the 2 men or the money.  One of the men pulled out a match.  They closed their eyes and the one with the lightable side had to jump out.  The man pulled the lightable end and jumped out.

D: He was an adventurer who, along with a companion, embarked on an ambitious desert expedition. They were ill-prepared for the harsh conditions and soon faced a dire shortage of food and water. In a moment of desperation, they agreed to a luck-of-the-draw matchstick game to decide who would venture out to seek help. He drew the shorter match but perished in the attempt, his body found with the remnant of that crucial decision clutched in his hand.

problem: A bricklayer has 9 bricks. 8 bricks weigh the same amount, but one brick is slightly heavier than the rest. The bricklayer wants to find the heavy brick. He has a balance scale. How can he find the heavy brick in only two weighings?
options: A: He should first divide the bricks into two groups of four and one group of one. Then, weigh one group of four against the other. If they balance, the heavy brick is in the single group set aside. Then, weigh two bricks from any group against each other. If they balance, the last brick is the heavy one. If not, the scale will show which is heavier.

B: He should divide the bricks into 3 groups of 3. He then weighs 2 sets of 3 bricks against each other. If they balance, the heavy brick is in the group that was set aside. If they do not balance, he then takes the group that was heaviest. He has 3 bricks left.  He takes the 2 bricks from the 3 and weighs them against each other. If they balance, the heavy brick is the one which is set aside. If they do not balance, the scale will show which is the heavier brick.

C: The bricklayer should stack all 9 bricks in a single pile and remove them one by one, weighing the remaining pile each time. When the scale's reading decreases more significantly than before, the brick removed most recently is the heavier one. This method finds the heavy brick in one weighing, assuming a consistent decrease for each lighter brick removed.

D: He needs to divide the bricks into three parts: four, four, and one. He weighs the two groups of four against each other. If they balance, he knows the heavy brick is the one not weighed. He then chooses any two bricks from the remaining eight and weighs them to find the heavier brick, assuming the imbalance will indicate the heavier one.

problem:
My first is a reptile to beware
My second is sometimes used to stare
I'm one combo for a cubic pair

What am I?
options:
A: Lizard look!
Explanation: This option plays on the reptilian theme with "lizard," another reptile to "beware" as indicated in Line 1. "Look" serves as a synonym for "stare," aligning with Line 2's clue but intentionally diverting from the accurate interpretation of dice numbers. This choice intentionally misleads by incorporating elements relevant to the description yet does not fit the context of a “cubic pair,” preserving the challenge.

B: snake eyes

Line 3 refers to one combination for a pair of dice ("a cubic pair"). A dice roll of two ones is referred to as "snake eyes".

C: Turtle glance!
Explanation: Mirroring the structure of the correct answer, this option employs "turtle," a less threatening reptile, potentially misleading given the "to beware" hint in Line 1. "Glance" as a variant of "stare" for Line 2 attempts to maintain relevance to the overall riddle's theme. However, it diverges significantly from the required context of dice, specifically the unique configuration known as "snake eyes," hence providing a subtly misleading alternative that still fits the puzzle's format and stylistic presentation.

D: Dragon gaze!
Explanation: Line 1 could lead to the misconception of a "dragon" due to its mythical reptilian nature, which could be a creature to beware. Line 2's "gaze" can mislead as another term for looking or "sometimes used to stare," attempting to tie in with the riddle but diverging from the correct concept of "snake eyes" related to dice. This option, however, fails to properly connect with the "cubic pair" concept from Line 3, misleading participants away from the correct answer.

problem:
When Troti (The Ruler of the Inspectors) walked into the house, a police officer approached him. "We have two people in custody," said the officer, "But we have to release them both if we can't find out who did this. There's Mary, a former business partner, but they got in an argument a while back and split the business up. Then there's Roger, her ex-boyfriend. When we came they were both looking at the body."

"Where are they?" said Troti.

"They are upstairs in the victim's room, where she was shot."

Troti walked upstairs to the room. He saw the body, the light from the open window illuminating the waist to the head. The window looked old, and there was no screen, just sliding glass. Through it you could see her backyard. There was a bullet high in her back. Troti looked at the suspects in the room. "I would like to have a word with both of you."

Mary walked out in the hall with Troti and began to speak with Troti. "I don't really know what happened. I heard the shot from my house, our houses are back to back. When I ran over I saw Roger pale as a ghost looking down at the body. I think Roger shot the poor girl. Even if I was angry at her, she didn't deserve what she got at all."

She reentered the room and Roger came out. "I came over to apologize to Julie. I knocked on the door, then heard a gunshot. I ran in and looked down at her. I was absolutely horrified at what I saw, but I didn't do it. Mary came over a few minutes later, saying she heard the shot from her house."

Troti then had an idea about who had murdered the girl. Do you know whom?
options: A: A third, unknown individual committed the crime. This theory suggests that there was another person with a motive against Julie, who cleverly executed the crime when Mary and Roger were nearby, framing them. This overlooks the specific details that aligned with Mary's involvement, such as the trajectory and origin point of the bullet, which directly tied back to the positioning of Mary's house.

B: Julie's death was an accident. The investigation overlooked the possibility of a stray bullet fired inadvertently from a distance. Such a scenario suggests an external force was responsible, dismissing the direct involvement of either Mary or Roger in the room. This theory, however, doesn't account for the specific trajectories that implicated Mary's unique position.

C: Roger shot Julie. Roger, overcome with guilt, managed to fabricate a story that matched the timing of Mary's arrival. His admission of being at the scene immediately after the gunshot was an attempt to establish an alibi prematurely. However, his narrative fails to consider the angle of the bullet, which points towards an external shooter, not someone within the room.

D: Mary shot Julie.

Julie was obviously face down because the bullet in her back was visible. But you know that she was standing with her back to the window because when she fell, the light was on the upper half of her body. You could not shoot her by coming in to the room. That means someone shot her through the open window. Roger had no access to any vantage points from where he could shoot her, yet Mary did. She shot the bullet from her window, which was just opposite hers, as their houses are back to back.

problem:
I'm coupled with a famous American dell
Which is linked to a device on your desk as well

Of this thing's brain, I am located at the base
And instances of my tail are found on its face

Should you be so inclined as to truncate my tail
Then you'll have a character who's landed in jail

When the chips are down, and you may be feeling blue
I'll be glad to furnish a new supply for you

What am I?
options:
A: silicon


lines 1-2: A "dell" is a valley. Silicon Valley is a high-tech dominated region of the San Francisco Bay area, which is in California, USA.
Silicon chips are used inside desktop (and other) computers.

lines 3-4: A computer's "brain" or central processing unit (CPU) is part of an integrated circuit (IC) chip, otherwise referred to as a silicon chip.
"My tail" is "icon" (sil-icon) and icons are found on a computer's screen ("its face").

lines 5-6: If you "truncate my tail" ("icon") then the result being referred to is "con", which is "a character who's landed in jail".

lines 7-8: The phrase "the chips are down" is alluding to silicon chips. Therefore, "a new supply" is referring to a new supply of silicon chips.

B: Copper!
   lines 1-2: Copper is a key element used in electronics for conductive wiring and is essential in the production of devices. However, it doesn't hold the same cultural or technological weight as Silicon Valley.
   lines 3-4: While copper is important in the production of electrical devices, it isn't located at the base of a computer's "brain" nor does it involve "icons" in any direct manner on the device's interface.
   lines 5-6: Removing any portion of "copper" does not result in a term that implies a person in jail, unlike the playful wordplay associated with silicon.
   lines 7-8: Although copper is crucial for electrical transmission within devices, it doesn't share the same urgent need for replenishment in the technological context as silicon, which is fundamental for chip production.

C: Plastic!
   lines 1-2: Plastic is a commonly used material in numerous devices and gadgets, including those found on your desk, though it doesn't share the same significance with Silicon Valley or technological advancement.
   lines 3-4: Unlike silicon, plastic does not serve as the basis for integrated circuits within computer hardware or other electronics, nor does the term "plastic" hide symbols like "icon" in its name.
   lines 5-6: Truncating any part of the word "plastic" does not leave us with a term that signifies a character who has landed in jail.
   lines 7-8: Plastic, although critical in the manufacturing of various components, doesn't directly relate to the supply of essential materials during hard times, unlike silicon chips which are pivotal to technological functionality and innovation.

D: Graphene!
   lines 1-2: Graphene, while heralded as a revolutionary material in electronics for its exceptional conductivity and strength, doesn't share the geographical or iconic connection with a technological hub like Silicon Valley.
   lines 3-4: Unlike silicon, graphene does not form the foundational base of the CPU or feature "icons" as part of its terminology or function within an electronic interface.
   lines 5-6: The word "graphene" cannot be truncated to reveal a term related to incarceration, making the play on words exclusive to the original answer, silicon.
   lines 7-8: Graphene, though promising in scientific research for future electronics, is not currently the source of a "new supply" in a practical, immediate sense like silicon chips, which are integral to maintaining technological progress and innovation.

problem:
After Andrew had been sick for a week, he asked his best friend Jesse to get his books out of his locker. Instead of telling Jesse the three number combination Andrew said he kept a small piece of paper with the combination under his locker door.

After school Jesse went to Andrew's locker and pulled the paper. On the paper was written:
24 24 22 9 9 9 9 22 24 22 9 9.

Thinking this would be easy but a little tedious, Jesse entered in every arrangement of 24, 22, and 9 there was without the lock opening. Realizing there was something behind these numbers that he wasn't noticing, Jesse sat down for a few minutes to think it out. After ten minutes of intense thinking, Jesse went to the locker, entered the combination into the lock and it opened.

What was the combination?
options:
A: 28, 4, 17.

Writing the 24th letter of the alphabet for each 24, the 22nd letter of the alphabet for each 22, and the 9th letter of the alphabet for each 9 reveals:
XXVIIIIVXVII

It is now clear that the combination is written in Roman Numerals. The only set of 3 Roman Numerals that fits this arrangement is:
XXVIII IV XVII or 28, 4, 17.

B: 15, 7, 8.
Interpreting the sequence as a direct numerical conversion to letters, they then applied a simple addition formula mistaken for a decoding method:
O (15), G (7), H (8). The added values meant to represent a step in each direction in an alphabetic sequence based on miscounted intervals was: XVII VII VIII or 15, 7, 8.

C: 26, 18, 9.
Analyzing the pattern as every two numbers representing a simple mathematical operation where 24 indicates no change, 22 is a subtraction by 6, and 9 represents division by itself, it was misunderstood: (24) X stays 24 or 26 in alphabet conversion error, (22) V becomes 18 after subtracting numerical value mistakenly included, (9) I ends up as 9 due to a misinterpreted division operation leading to: XXVI XVIII IX or 26, 18, 9.

D: 10, 14, 22.
Writing the numbers as positions in the alphabet then converting those letters into their numerical positions in reverse order (A=26, Z=1) gives: J (10), N (14), V (22). Considering the decoding was misplaced, they mistakenly thought to reverse compute the values.

problem: You have stealthily raided your small child's piggy bank. You feel guilty as you count the money. You have the same number of dimes and quarters, totaling exactly $2.45. When you turn honest and put it back, how many of each coin will you need to replace? (Note that your child keeps a record of how much she puts in and in what denomination)
options:
A: Let x represent the number of dimes, which is the same as the quarters. Then 10x represents the value of the dimes (x times 10 cents), and 25x represents the value of the quarters, in cents.

10x + 25x = 245
35x = 240
x = 6.86

Therefore, there were about 6 dimes and 6 quarters totaling exactly $2.45

B: Let x represent the number of dimes, which is the same as the quarters. Then 10x represents the value of the dimes (x times 10 cents), and 25x represents the value of the quarters, in cents.

10x + 25x = 245
35x = 245
x = 7

Therefore, there were 7 dimes and 7 quarters totaling exactly $2.45

C: Let x represent the number of dimes, the same as the number of quarters. Therefore, the value equation for the dimes is 10x (x times 10 cents), and for the quarters, it's 25x (x times 25 cents).

10x + 25x = 245
35x = 250
x = 7.14

Consequently, you would need approximately 7 dimes and 7 quarters, totaling nearly $2.45.

D: Consider x as the number of dimes, equal to the number of quarters. The dimes value is given by 10x (x times 10 cents) and the quarters value by 25x (x times 25 cents).

10x + 25x = 245
30x = 245
x = 8.17

As a result, there were roughly 8 dimes and 8 quarters to total exactly $2.45.

There are five guys (Dewey, Cheatem, Howe, Hackneyed, and Jokendunnit) who have different favorite snacks (bacon botty, Grandma Utz potato chips, pecan log, topfenstrudel, and Vegemite), sit on different seats (Barcalounger, chaise, couch, Lay-Z-Boy, and slipper chair), and watch different things on TV (The A-Team, Family Guy, the Marx Brothers, The Simpsons, and the Three Stooges). 8. The owner of the couch loves pecans, and snacks on them while watching The Simpsons.

B: Dewey eats topfenstrudel while watching The Marx Brothers on his Lay-Z-Boy.
