BDGJPQR
COSU

Which row does the missing letter belong to and why?
options: A: "Q" belongs in the top row. The top row consists of letters that do not have enclosed spaces, differentiating letters based on their structural characteristics in terms of enclosed areas.

B: "U" belongs in the middle row. The middle row includes letters that are taller or extend beyond the typical x-height in typography, focusing on the letters' visual height in relation to standard typographical guidelines.

C: "L" belongs in the top row. 

The top row is letters that are written using only straight lines, the middle row is letters that use both straight and curved lines and the bottom row is letters that use only curved lines.

D: "E" belongs in the bottom row. The bottom row is for letters that represent vowels in the English alphabet, showcasing a distinct categorization based on the letters' roles in vowel and consonant classification.

problem:
This is a quote by a very famous person. Can you decipher it?  I won't include capitals in the cipher. 

"oltsitemsienevfruodngania." 

-ebjnmanirfnalkni
options:
A: To decipher: put a space after every 2 letters. Except for the last three letters. Leave them be: olts - ol ts. nia - nia. Then, switch the two (or three) letters around: ol ts - lo st. Nia - ain. Repeat for the next letters: lo st ti me is ne ve rf ou nd ag ain. Put them together, minus spaces: losttimeisneverfoundagain. Then, look at the title: 4, 4, 2, 5, 5, 5, 8, 8... they represent letters before a space: lost time is never found again. Use this rule (this time, all letters are the same) for the last part. 

It now should read: 

Lost time is never found again. 
-Benjamin Franklin.

B: Time once gone is never returned.
-Alexander Hamilton.

C: Moments passed cannot be recaptured.
-George Washington.

D: Time lost is never regained.
-Thomas Jefferson.

problem:
Of all the words; we are four
All rhyming down to the core

You will find a judge in the first
The second; the amount of time to quench your thirst

The third, a place to keep your ship
In the last you can dip, maybe even do a flip

Now tell me what these four words are
And you just might go really far

Can you decipher this phrase:

Hamlet
Words

I have five letters.
If you take the first and last,
I will still be the same.
Even if you take the middle letter,
I will be the same as before.
What am I?
options: A: The word QUIET! If you take away the first and last letters, you have UIE, which is pronounced differently. If you take away the middle letter, you have QUET, still pronounced differently!
B: The word BRAVE! Taking the first and last letters off leaves you with RAV, changing its pronunciation. Removing the middle letter results in BAE, which sounds different from the original!
C: I am EMPTY. If you take away the first and last letters, you have MPT, which is pronounced the same way. If you take away the middle letter, you have EMTY, still pronounced the same!

D: The word LIGHT! If you remove the first and last letters, it becomes IG, which does not maintain the sound. Removing the middle letter gives you LHT, which also alters the pronunciation significantly!

problem:
"I know we should have called the police," Eric Wembly admitted as he nursed a bump on the back of his head. "But the kidnapper said he'd kill my brother if we did. And it's not like we couldn't afford the ransom."

John Wembly, the elder son of Jonas Wembly, had been missing since Tuesday. On Wednesday morning, a lone kidnapper telephoned the mansion and made his demands. The younger Wembly son, Eric, was to bring the money in unmarked bills in a duffel bag. He was to take a specific route from the mansion, parking in a downtown lot and carrying the bag through an alley to a drop site in a nearby park.

The normally cheap Jonas Wembly was frantic and willingly agreed to the terms. A midnight pay-off. Half a million dollars. And no police.

"I was halfway through the alley," Eric testified, "when I heard footsteps. Before I could turn around I was hit on the head. I fell down. But it didn't quite knock me out. I could see his back by the light of a street lamp. Never got to see his front. He was running away with the duffel bag. A tall guy with white sneakers. He was wearing blue jeans and a dark cardigan. Sorry I can't be more specific."

In the case's one lucky break, a police officer came across Eric shortly after the attack. He called in the crime and a patrol car responded immediately. Two suspicious-looking characters were apprehended in the vicinity, both resembling Eric's description.

"So, I was running," Petey Bordon said angrily. He had been found two blocks from the attack and started running as soon as he saw the patrol car. Petey had a string of priors, all misdemeanors. "I'm on parole," he admitted, "And I was carrying a knife -- for my own protection at night. That's a violation. Can you wonder why I ran away?"

The second suspect was Arnie Acker, a homeless drifter. "I wasn't even wearing this sweater," he protested as he unbuttoned his moth-eaten cardigan. "I picked it out of the garbage just before you guys pulled me in."

"We didn't find money on either one of 'em," the chief of police told Jonas Wembly. "And we didn't find the duffel bag. But I got a pretty good idea what happened. Don't worry. We'll get your son back."

Who kidnapped John Wembly?
options: A: Petey Bordon. Petey's nervous behavior and his choice to flee from the police might suggest guilt, but his priors were only misdemeanors, and he had no known link to the victim beyond being in the wrong place at the wrong time.

B: Eric Wembly.

Eric's testimony about the cardigan sweater gave him away. If Eric saw his attacker only from the rear, as he claimed, then it would have been impossible to tell if he was wearing a cardigan or a pullover. Eric was obviously lying.

Eric eventually confessed, admitting that he and John had staged the entire kidnapping scene in order to extract money from their cheap father.

C: Jonas Wembly. Despite his portrayal as a worried father, considering his wealth and uncharacteristic willingness to pay the ransom without involving the police could imply a deeper involvement or a staged scheme for an unknown motive.

D: Arnie Acker. Found wearing a dark cardigan similar to the one described by Eric and being in the vicinity of the crime scene might raise suspicions. However, his explanation of finding the sweater just before being apprehended could indicate his innocence in the actual kidnapping plot.

problem:
A mansion I am
For many, many things.
I can live for a very long time.
As I grow,
I wear more jewelry;
However, my jewelry is hidden.
Only when I die
Do others find
How old I've grown
And just where my jewelry lies.
options:
A: A coral reef!
A coral reef grows and thrives, housing diverse life forms, akin to "wearing jewelry." Its true age and the intricate life it supports remain largely unseen until it is damaged or dies, at which point the layers of growth and history can be studied, reflecting how a tree's rings are hidden until its end.

B: A mountain!
Mountains endure through ages, their appearances changing with erosion and vegetation growth, symbolizing the "jewelry" they adorn over time. Their geological layers, much like tree rings, tell stories of their extensive history, but this depth and narrative often remain concealed until investigated by geologists after the mountain has been altered or eroded.

C: A tree.

The rings of trees tell how old a tree is. When a tree is cut down, the number of rings can be seen to tell just how old the tree is. Before it is cut down, you cannot see the number of rings.

D: A castle!
A castle can stand for centuries, embodying history and grandeur. It accumulates artifacts and treasures within its walls. Yet, only upon its ruins or through exploration do its secrets and the full extent of its age become known, much like the hidden 'jewelry' of a tree's age rings.

problem: Consider a vertical wheel of radius 10 cm. Now suppose a smaller wheel of radius 2 cm, is made to roll around the larger wheel in the same vertical plane while the larger wheel remains fixed. What is the total number of rotations the smaller wheel makes when its center makes one complete rotation about the larger wheel?
options: A: 5 rotations. If you initiate the rotation of the smaller wheel along with the larger wheel without rolling them through one complete clockwise turn, the small wheel completes 1 turn clockwise. Subsequently, by rotating the larger wheel back to its original position counter-clockwise through one rotation, while keeping the center of the small wheel fixed but allowing the wheel to roll without sliding, it is incorrectly assumed to result in 4 additional turns due to the ratio of the circumferences of the wheels. Therefore, the proposed total number of rotations of the small wheel is wrongly calculated as 4 + 1 = 5.

B: The correct answer is 6 rotations. Suppose you rotate the smaller wheel and the larger wheel together without rolling through one rotation clockwise, the small wheel has rotated through 1 turn clockwise. Now rotate the larger wheel back to its original position counter-clockwise through one rotation at the same time holding the center of the small wheel in the original position but allowing the wheel to rotate without sliding. It will rotate through 5 more turns due to the ratio of the circumferences of the wheels. The total number of rotations of the small wheel is 5 + 1 = 6.

C: 4 rotations. Imagine rotating both the smaller wheel and the larger wheel together without rolling for one rotation in a clockwise direction, which results in the small wheel completing 1 turn clockwise. Then, by rotating the larger wheel back to its starting position counter-clockwise through one rotation, while maintaining the center of the small wheel stationary but permitting the wheel to rotate without sliding, it is mistaken to result in an extra 3 turns because of the circumferential differences. Thus, the total number of rotations of the small wheel is inaccurately counted as 3 + 1 = 4.

D: 3 rotations. Suppose you rotate the smaller and larger wheel together without rolling through one rotation clockwise, the small wheel has rotated through 1 turn clockwise. Now, by rotating the larger wheel back to its original position counter-clockwise through one rotation while keeping the center of the small wheel in its initial position but allowing the wheel to rotate without sliding, it is perceived that it will rotate through an additional 2 turns due to the difference in circumferences. The total number of rotations of the small wheel is perceived as 2 + 1 = 3.

problem:
King Arthur, Merlin, Sir Lancelot, Sir Gawain, and Guinevere decide to go to their favorite restaurant to share some mead and grilled meats.  They sit down at a round table for five, and as soon as they do, Lancelot notes, "We sat down around the table in age order!  What are the odds of that?"  

Merlin smiles broadly.  "This is easily solved without any magic."  He then shared the answer.  What did he say the odds were?
options:
A: The odds are 23:1. (The probability is 1/24.)

Imagine they sat down randomly without considering their age order. Given that the first person to pick a seat sets the starting point, they have no constraint. The second oldest, however, has a 2 out of 5 chance of sitting next to the first person in age order since they could sit in any of the remaining four seats but only two would maintain age order adjacent to the first person. Thus, the odds for the third person are 1 out of 4, as they must pick the one seat that continues the age sequence correctly. The odds for the fourth person to sit correctly by age are then calculated as 1 out of 3, leading to the youngest having a guaranteed correct seat. The calculation would then falsely suggest 1 * 2/5 * 1/4 * 1/3 * 1, equating to 1/24 or 23:1 odds against.

B: The odds are 5:1. (The probability is 1/6.)

Consider the arrangement where the first person who sits down does so with no specific orientation, automatically aligning with age order. For the second oldest, there's essentially a choice of 5 seats, but with the orientation (clockwise or counterclockwise) two favorable options exist out of the four possibilities, giving a 2/5 chance. For the third person, the probability was incorrectly estimated to be 1/4 because they appear to have four seats to choose from, only one of which will be correct, ignoring the correct ongoing sequence. Similarly, the fourth person supposedly has a 1 out of 3 chance, maintaining the sequence wrongfully. This leads to a miscalculated probability sequence of 1 * 2/5 * 1/4 * 1/3 * 1 = 1/6, or 5:1 odds against.

C: The odds are 11:1.  (The probability is 1/12.)

Imagine they sat down in age order, with each person randomly picking a seat.  The first person is guaranteed to pick a seat that "works".  The second oldest can sit to his right or left, since these five can sit either clockwise or counterclockwise.  The probability of picking a seat that works is thus 2/4, or 1/2.  The third oldest now has three chairs to choose from, one of which continues the progression in the order determined by the second person, for a probability of 1/3.  This leaves two seats for the fourth oldest, or a 1/2 chance.  The youngest would thus be guaranteed to sit in the right seat, since there is only one seat left.  This gives 1 * 1/2 * 1/3 * 1/2 * 1 = 1/12, or 11:1 odds against.

D: The odds are 19:1. (The probability is 1/20.)

In this scenario, the argument might start with the assumption that any of the five can sit in any seat as the first person, setting a base that doesn't affect the odds. However, for the second to sit correctly, there is a supposed 3 out of 5 chance, mistakingly considering seats on both immediate sides plus an erroneous extra option. The third has a 2 out of 4 chance by this flawed logic, supposedly leaving two correct options to maintain age order. For the fourth, the incorrect calculation gives them a 50% chance (1 out of 2), neglecting the proper sequence's establishment entirely. The sequence falsely presented as 1 * 3/5 * 2/4 * 1/2 * 1 = 1/20, representing 19:1 odds against.

problem:
I am a womb;
My life I live to nourish my sweet inside me.
I am a cocoon;
I protect this tender body from elemental battery.

But what do I receive for all that I give? 
It is only for my fruit that I am suffered to live. 
I am cut from my parents before I reach maturity, 
I am labeled and carried off, to await much scrutiny. 

And you, who's never contemplated the importance of my duty, 
Will take me in your hands only when you judge me to be a beauty. 
And then will you appreciate the importance of my labor?
No. It is only my sweet that you will savor.

You may decide to utilize me 
In your plan to comically foil a villain. 
You may decide to utilize me 
To feed your organic arugula garden.

But chances are you'll find 
That you have no use for me. 
I'm old and soft and bruised, 
And I bore you with my story.

But such is the life of a mother, 
Who will give all to son and daughter.
And such is the death of a mother, 
Who will die without glory and honor. 

Who is this (vainglorious) heroine?

You are reading a book and you come across the word minute. You know instantly that the word is minute (small) and not minute (60 seconds). You did not conclude this based on the words before or after it, its placement in the sentence, or the title of the book. What the book is about is irrelevant. The book is written in English, and the answer is NOT that the print was small.

So, how did you know the word was minute (small) and not minute (60 seconds)?
options: A: The word was capitalized mid-sentence, leading you to believe it was minute (small), as proper nouns or specific titles might be capitalized for emphasis, and in this case, the author chose to stylize the word uniquely to draw attention to its meaning.

B: The word was hyphenated (half at the end of one line and the rest at the beginning of the next line). When this happens, the word is separated between the syllables. The two words separate at different points, as minute (small) would appear as mi-nute and minute (60 seconds) would appear as min-ute.

C: The word followed a number, typically indicating a measurement or quantification, suggesting it was minute (60 seconds) since numerical values preceding words often refer to units of time or quantity, misleading about its true pronunciation and meaning in this context.

D: The word was italicized, which is a common way to emphasize foreign or technical terms, thus indicating it was minute (small) due to its specialized usage in the context it was presented, which is often differentiated by font style.

problem: You have two ropes. Each takes exactly 60 minutes to burn. They are made of different material so even though they take the same amount of time to burn, they burn at separate rates. In addition, each rope burns inconsistently. How do you measure out exactly 45 minutes?
options: A: Light one rope at one end and wait for it to burn completely. As soon as the first rope is fully burned, light the second rope at one end. When the second rope has burned halfway, you have measured 45 minutes.

B: Burn both ropes at one end, then when the first rope finishes burning (60 minutes), immediately light the second end of the same rope. This will supposedly measure out another 30 minutes for a total of 90 minutes.

C: Take one rope and burn it at both ends.
At the same time, burn one end of the
other rope. When the first rope finishes
burning (ie. 30 minutes), light the other
end of the remaining rope (half of the
remaining 30 minutes gives you 15 minutes)
When it burns out, that`s 45 minutes.
D: Begin by burning both ropes at one end. When the first rope burns out (after 60 minutes), light the other end of the second rope. When it finishes burning, you have measured 90 minutes in total.

problem:
Maria doesn't like to tell people her real age. When somebody asks her how old she is, she says that she is twenty-one. (Maria mentally omits all Sundays because on Sundays she doesn't work, so she claims she doesn't get any older.) 

How old is Maria really?
options:
A: Maria is possibly between 28 and 29 years. She claims she subtracts one-ninth of her real age.

If she were really 28.9 years old, she might claim to be 21 (28.9 * 8/9 = 25.7 (rounded)). 

If she were really 29.7 years old, she could also claim to be 21 (29.7 * 8/9 = 26.4 (rounded)).

B: Maria could be either 22 or 23. She subtracted one-sixth of her real age. 

If she were actually 22.2 years old, she could claim that she was 21 (22.2 * 5/6 = 18.5 (rounded)). 

If she were actually 23.4 years old, she could also claim that she was 21 (23.4 * 5/6 = 19.5 (rounded)).

C: Maria could be either 24 or 25.  She subtracted one-seventh of her real age.

If she were actually 24.5 years old, she could claim that she was 21 (24.5 * 6/7 = 21).

If she were actually 25.6 years old, she could also claim that she was 21 (25.6 * 6/7 = 21.9 (rounded)).

D: Maria might be either 26 or 27. She subtracted one-eighth of her real age. 

If she were actually 26.8 years old, she could claim she was 21 (26.8 * 7/8 = 23.45). 

If she were actually 27.9 years old, she could also claim she was 21 (27.9 * 7/8 = 24.4 (rounded)).

Group B: Bewitched, Friends, Home Improvement, Lost in Space, Night Court, The Mary Tyler Moore Show
options: A: Lost in Space, since the series featured two robots portraying the role of the Robot, adding a subtle hint towards the shared thematic element of dual representation in Group A.
B: Home Improvement, because the series showcased different Houses of Horror episodes, aligning with the thematic transitions noted in Group A series.

C: Each series in Group A had one of its lead characters played by more than one person.  Pete Duel and Roger Davis played Hannibal Heyes in "Alias Smith & Jones".  Jeannine Riley, Gunilla Hutton, and Meredith MacRae played Billie Jo Bradley in "Petticoat Junction".  Janet Hubert and Daphne Reid played Vivian Banks in "The Fresh Prince of Bel Air".  Beverly Owen and Pat Priest played Marilyn Munster in "The Munsters".  Thus, "Bewitched", with both Dick York and Dick Sargent playing Darrin Stephens, can be added to Group A.
D: The Mary Tyler Moore Show, given the iteration of characters in varying professional roles, reflecting a fluidity similar to the character switches in Group A.

Hickory, dickory, dock, a mouse has messed up the clock. Something, at least, has messed up the old alarm clock in Randy's bedroom. Sometimes it runs backward, with the hands moving counter-clockwise.

Randy's clock is a standard 12-hour analog clock.

What time will the clock now show?
options:
A: The time shown is 4:13, or 13 minutes after 4. 

In the realm of time, we navigate by units of 12 (hours) and 60 (minutes). 

Initially, Randy's clock indicated 45 minutes past 9. 

Surviving the first backward journey of 14 hours and 6 minutes landed it again at the same point, following the traditional 12-hour reset. Subsequently, a miscalculation led to an additional retreat of 2 hours and 6 minutes, incorrectly placing it at 13 minutes past 4, disregarding the specified subsequent movements and their careful calculations.

Post the initial 14 hours and 6 minutes of reversal, it found its way back to the starting point, disregarding accurate subtraction for further steps. The premature conclusion of events and an overlooked calculation of forward and subsequent backward movements erroneously sets the clock at 4 minutes after 3, failing to accurately navigate through the detailed temporal adjustments.

C: The clock will show 2:51, or 51 minutes after 2.

In considering time, we have to think in units of 12 (hours) and 60 (minutes).

The clock showed 45 minutes after 9 when Randy first checked it.

After the first 12 hours of the 14 hours and 6 minutes of running backward, the clock was back at 45 minutes after 9. Then it ran back an additional 2 hours and 6 minutes to 39 minutes after 7.

After running forward for 5 hours and 53 minutes, the clock showed 32 minutes after 1.

After going backward again for 1 hour, the clock showed 32 minutes after 12. Then, after it ran back the remaining 9 hours and 41 minutes, it showed 51 minutes after 2.

D: The clock will show 1:28, or 28 minutes after 1. 

In considering time, we have to think in units of 12 (hours) and 60 (minutes). 

The clock showed 45 minutes after 9 when Randy first checked it. 

After the first 12 hours of the 14 hours and 6 minutes of running backward, the clock was at 45 minutes after 9 again. It then moved back an additional 2 hours and 6 minutes to 39 minutes after 7. 

Running forward for 5 hours and 53 minutes brought the clock to 32 minutes after 1. 

A final backward motion for 10 hours and 41 minutes, rather than properly accounting for the time, incorrectly places it at 28 minutes after 1.

A hundred and one
by fifty divide,
And if a cipher
is rightly applied,
The answer is one from nine.
options:
A: CLIO
Using Roman numerals, a hundred and one is CI and fifty is L.  Dividing CI by L gives CLI.  Add cypher (0) to the right gives the answer: Clio, being the name of one of the nine muses from Greek Mythology.

B: VESTA - Using Roman numerals, a hundred is C and one is I, making CI. Fifty is L, which could misleadingly be subtracted instead of divided, resulting in an erroneous interpretation. By mistakenly adding a cipher (0) on the left instead of the right, one could misinterpret VESTA, another name from mythology, as the answer.

C: ERATO - Incorrectly using the arithmetic operation of addition instead of division, one might misinterpret a hundred and one (CI) plus fifty (L) as CLI, disregarding the original arithmetic instruction. Adding a cipher (0) inappropriately in the calculation could lead someone to incorrectly deduce ERATO, confusing her with the muse Clio.

D: URANIA - Misapplying the division operation by reversing the divisor and the dividend, one might divide L (50) by CI (101), leading to a mathematical error. Following this, adding a cipher (0) incorrectly to the result could misleadingly point to URANIA, another of the nine muses, instead of the correct answer, Clio.

problem: Mad Ade regularly plays chess with his best friend, Dim Dave McLoweyecue. They play just one game per day and the loser must give the winner a kebab. After a period of time Mad Ade had bought Dim Dave 5 kebabs whereas Dim Dave had bought Mad Ade 21 kebabs. So how many games were played in total if there were no tied matches?
options:
A: Dim Dave McLoweyecue received 5 kebabs and won 5 games. Mad Ade received 21 kebabs and won 21 games. 

Thus, the total number of games that they played was 26.
B: Dim Dave McLoweyecue received 5 kebabs and won 5 games. Mad Ade received 20 kebabs and won 20 games. Thus, the total number of games that they played was 25.
C: Dim Dave McLoweyecue received 6 kebabs and won 6 games. Mad Ade received 20 kebabs and won 20 games. Thus, the total number of games that they played was 26.
D: Dim Dave McLoweyecue received 4 kebabs and won 4 games. Mad Ade received 22 kebabs and won 22 games. Thus, the total number of games that they played was 26.

problem:
Mad Ade is telling his friend, Shamus O'Stoatclencher, at which number house he lives at on "Madadia Avenue":

(1) If my house number is a multiple of 3, then it is a number from 50 through 59. 

(2) If my house number is not a multiple of 4, then it is a number from 60 through 69. 

(3) If my house number is not a multiple of 6, then it is a number from 70 through 79."

What is Mad Ade's house number?
options:
A: Mad Ade's house number is 76. 

From (1) and (3), the house number must be from 50 to 59 or 70 to 79. Take any number. It will be either a multiple of 3 or not. Also, a number multiple of 6 is always a multiple of 3. Hence, the house number can be 51, 54, 57, 70, 71, 73, 74, 76, 77 or 79. 

From (2), if the house number is not a multiple of 4, then it is a number from 60 through 69. There is not a single number between 60 and 69 in short-listed numbers above. Hence, the house number must be a multiple of 4 i.e. 76.

Hence, Mad Ade's house number is 76.

B: 57!  
Given the premises (1) and (3), we deduce that the range for Mad Ade's house number narrows down to either between 50 to 59 or 70 to 79. Delving into the possibilities, we sift through potential numbers being 51, 54, 57, 70, 71, 73, 74, 76, 77, or 79 based on their relationship or lack thereof with the number 3. Misinterpretation of clue (2) might lead to the mistaken belief that because there are no candidates between 60 and 69, and ignoring the multiplicity with 4, one could erroneously deduce 57 as a likely candidate, disregarding the logical deduction needed to isolate the correct number.  
Thus, a misguided deduction could mistakenly identify Mad Ade's house number as 57.

C: 74!  
From (1) and (3), the house number must be from 50 to 59 or 70 to 79. Take any number. It will be either a multiple of 3 or not. Also, a number multiple of 6 is always a multiple of 3. Hence, the house number can be 51, 54, 57, 70, 71, 73, 74, 76, 77, or 79.  
From (2), if the house number is not a multiple of 4, then it is a number from 60 through 69. There is not a single number between 60 and 69 in the short-listed numbers above. Hence, one might incorrectly conclude the house number must be a multiple of 4 i.e. 74.  
Hence, an incorrect guess could be that Mad Ade's house number is 74.

D: 54!  
By analyzing (1) and (3), it appears that Mad Ade's house number could either be from 50 to 59 or 70 to 79. Evaluating further, the house numbers such as 51, 54, 57, 70, 71, 73, 74, 76, 77, or 79 emerge as candidates based on their multiplicity with 3 or their exclusion thereof. Considering the condition in (2), someone might erroneously conclude that the absence of numbers from 60 to 69 among the candidates posits that the house number aligns with being a multiple of 4, such as 54, misleadingly disregarding the correct interpretation of the given clues.  
Therefore, an incorrect interpretation might lead to the conclusion that Mad Ade’s house number is 54.

B: No authentic coin can be dated B.C.  Back when it was happening, no one knew the era would be called B.C.

problem:
Beird Waker, the celebrated poet, finally won a Booker for his thirteenth anthology of poems. In the post event party, you are in the circle surrounding the poet when Miss Gee, another guest, asks him innocently, "Do you actually remember the order in which your books were published?" This one liner sends the poet into a monologue:

"Aah, let's see.. I got the Booker for "Figments", which, as you know, is my thirteenth book.. but the first was a book called "Candy Floss", which, if I may say so, appears rather puerile when I read it now.. "Bubbles" was right after "Silence", but way before "Kingdom" . "Horsecarts" was after "Durian" but before "Kingdom" again. "Echo" and "Reverberations" were next to each other. "Mindreading" came just after "Reverberations" and just before "Glenfiddich", but even Glenfiddich was before "Kingdom" for sure.

"Oppression" was my bestseller, but sadly it wasn't the first book. I wish it was, it came a close second, but by then the market already had a perception about me.

"Elephant Song" and "Echo" had 2 books between them. "Silence" and "Elephant Song" had as many books between them as did "Bubbles" and "Durian". But, "Bubbles" was definitely published before "Elephant Song"."

Fred ran a flag making business. Things were looking bleak when, out of the blue, someone called from the Paraguayan Embassy. They needed an urgent consignment of 1000 Paraguayan flags by the following week.

Fred got to work straight away. He got a picture of the current Paraguayan flag, got hold of the required cloth and he and his staff worked without stopping until the flags were dispatched. The business was saved, or so he thought.

Unfortunately, the Embassy refused to pay and returned them all. Fred has now lost his business, but why?
options: A: Paraguay's flag has two different sides. Fred's picture only gave one side and that design was used front and back. Had he used a real flag for reference he could have turned it over and seen the difference.

B: The colors of the flag were inaccurately reproduced. Despite having the correct design, Fred's team failed to match the exact shades of red, white, and blue as specified by the Paraguayan Embassy, resulting in a batch of flags that did not adhere to the official standards.

C: Fred used inappropriate material for the flags, which did not meet the Paraguayan Embassy's standards for durability and weather resistance. He chose a fabric based solely on availability and cost, without considering the specifications necessary for national flags.

D: The flags were made with incorrect dimensions, making them unsuitable for official use. Fred had misinterpreted the size requirements from the instruction he received, leading to a complete rejection of the consignment by the Embassy.

problem:
There are two groups of four-letter words used in the sentences below. The first missing words of each sentence are anagrams of each other, and the second missing words are also anagrams of each other. Can you find them ?

1. The ______ gender of this king of animals has an astounding _____ of hair around his regal and fearful face.

2. That's a ______ excuse, you cannot get away without giving us the _____ of the person who helped you in this theft.

3. Before each ______, it is customary to say Grace and end with _______.
options:
A: 1. The MALE gender of this king of animals has an astounding MANE of hair around his regal and fearful face.

2. That's a LAME excuse, you cannot get away without giving us the NAME of the person who helped you in this theft.

3. Before each MEAL, it is customary to say Grace and end with AMEN.

Anagram groups -

Group 1 : MALE, LAME, MEAL
Group 2 : MANE, NAME, AMEN
B: That's a WEAK excuse, you cannot get away without giving us the WISE of the person who helped you in this theft.

C: Before each WELL, it is customary to say Grace and end with WALE.

Anagram groups -
Group 1 : WILD, WEAK, WELL
Group 2 : WAVE, WISE, WALE

2: 1. The FINE gender of this king of animals has an astounding FAME of hair around his regal and fearful face.
2. That's a FAIR excuse, you cannot get away without giving us the FIRE of the person who helped you in this theft.
3. Before each FEAT, it is customary to say Grace and end with FATE.

Anagram groups -
Group 1 : FINE, FAIR, FEAT
Group 2 : FAME, FIRE, FATE

3: 1. The CORE gender of this king of animals has an astounding CARE of hair around his regal and fearful face.
2. That's a RACE excuse, you cannot get away without giving us the ACRE of the person who helped you in this theft.
3. Before each ORCA, it is customary to say Grace and end with AERO.

Anagram groups -
Group 1 : CORE, RACE, ORCA
Group 2 : CARE, ACRE, AERO
D: 1. The WILD gender of this king of animals has an astounding WAVE of hair around his regal and fearful face.

problem:
Swaff and his older brother Abjar were once again talking to each other. This time, it was about their toast topping preferences. Abjar decided to play a little joke on Swaff.

He told him this story:

"When I was a young lad, back in the good ole year of 1902, my best friend, Geoff, and I would get into many crazy competitions. This one time, we decided to see who could get the bread to pop out of the toaster the farthest. I won with an amazing 19 inches."

Swaff was amazed. He never knew his brother was that cool.

Later on in life, Abjar revealed that this was a lie. How could Swaff have caught the lie?
options: A: Abjar couldn't have made toast in 1902 the way he described because bread slicing machines weren't widely available until after Otto Frederick Rohwedder perfected his design in the 1920s. Before this innovation, bread was not consistently sliced, making such toasting competitions impractical and less common.

B: Since Charles Strite invented the modern pop-up toaster in 1919, there was no way that Abjar and Geoff could have had a competition 17 years prior to its invention. Back then, the toasters were completely manual. You had to take the bread out, and flip it around to toast both sides. If Swaff would have caught this simple fact, he would have not had to go through such embarrassment.

C: The story was implausible because the concept of electrical power in homes to operate such a toaster was not common until the late 1920s. Most households in 1902 would not have had the electrical infrastructure to support the use of an electric toaster, making Abjar's competition story highly unlikely.

D: It was impossible for Abjar's story to be true because the record for the "farthest bread pop" was not established until the late 20th century. Competitive distances for toast popping as a recognized event did not exist in 1902, implying that Abjar’s claim of setting such a record was fabricated.

D: 85 and 97. According to this incorrect pattern, one might calculate by doubling the difference between the two digits of each number and adding this to the original number to find the next. While seemingly plausible, this does not accurately reflect the true pattern but is designed to mimic a mathematical approach.

A boy was putting on a show called 'Winter Magical Tricks'. Today he only wanted to put on one show. 
The audience had to guess how he did it, and if they got it 100% right they could win up to fifty dollars.

The magician gave a volunteer from the audience 5 twenty-cent coins. Each of the coins was identical except for the dates.  The magician then walked off the stage while the volunteer put the coins in the cup. Then the volunteer took out a coin, noted the date, and then held it tightly in his hands. When the magician came back on to the stage, he started to ask the volunteer questions. This is how the following questions were answered:

'What is your name?'
'Harry.'
'How old are you?'
'13.'
'What is your favorite food?'
'Chocolate'.
'Do you think you're about to get 50 dollars for deciphering this trick?'
'I don't think so.' 

Then the volunteer put the coin back in the cup while the magician was turned the other way. The cup was then given to the magician, who dumped the coins into his hand. 
'According to this, the coin you were holding was made in 1892.' 
'How did you do that?'

Can you decipher how the magician worked this out?
options: A: The magician used a special cup that recorded the weight of the coins individually. He could then tell which coin had been handled due to subtle changes in weight caused by skin oils.

B: The magician had memorized the slight differences in the texture of each coin's edge. Upon feeling the coins after they were given back to him, he detected the one that had been handled due to the warmth softening its sharp edges slightly.

C: Before the show, the magician applied a nearly invisible, heat-sensitive liquid to one side of each coin. The volunteer's hand warmed the coin enough to activate the liquid, leaving a temporary mark only the magician could identify.
D: The boy's hands warmed the coin up.  Since this was the "Winter Magical Tricks" show, the coins were initially cold.  The magician simply noted which coin was the warmest.

problem:
What value completes this series?

Sun, Moon, Mars, Mercury, Jupiter, Venus, ?
options:
A: Saturn

The Roman names for the days of the week were based on the heavenly bodies:
Sunday was the Roman dies Solis or day of the Sun.
Monday was the Roman dies Lunae or day of the Moon.
Tuesday was the Roman dies Martis or day of Mars.
Wednesday was the Roman dies Mercurii or day of Mercury.
Thursday was the Roman dies Jovis or day of Jove (Jupiter).
Friday was the Roman dies Veneris or day of Venus.
Saturday was the Roman dies Saturni or day of Saturn.

In English, it is easy to see the origins of Sunday, Monday and Saturday. In the Romance languages, it is easy to see the origins of the other days. For example, mardi (Tuesday in French) bears a resemblance to Mars; mercredi (Wednesday in French) bears a resemblance to Mercury.

B: Neptune
The Roman names for the days of the week were inspired by celestial bodies and mythical gods:
Sunday is associated with the Sun, reflecting its brightness and centricity.
Monday aligns with the Moon, symbolizing reflection and change.
Tuesday connects to Mars, representing energy and war.
Wednesday ties to Mercury, indicating communication and speed.
Thursday is linked to Jupiter, denoting power and leadership.
Friday corresponds to Venus, reflecting beauty and love.
Hence, Neptune, associated with the sea and dreams, seems a thematic extension, though not traditionally part of this weekly naming schema.

C: Earth
Drawing from Roman legacies and the cosmos:
Sunday radiates with the Sun, signifying origin and clarity.
Monday moves with the Moon, manifesting phases and reflection.
Tuesday is emblazoned with Mars, epitomizing drive and determination.
Wednesday wends with Mercury, indicating movement and exchange.
Thursday is joined with Jupiter, symbolizing growth and fortune.
Friday flourishes with Venus, embodying allure and connections.
Earth, embodying home and stability, presents a logical sequence, nonetheless not traditionally counted among these mythic correlations.

D: Pluto
In the framework of Roman mythology and celestial bodies:
Sunday shines with the Sun, embodying vitality and life.
Monday mirrors the Moon, revealing cycles and transitions.
Tuesday is marked by Mars, symbolizing action and courage.
Wednesday is wedded to Mercury, representing intellect and dexterity.
Thursday thrives with Jupiter, expressing expansion and wisdom.
Friday unfurls with Venus, showcasing attraction and harmony.
Pluto, ruling the underworld and transformation, conceptually follows, despite not being a classical part of the sequence.

problem:
Which word from Group B belongs in Group A?

Group A:
Cling
Drive
Fort
State

Group B:
Motion
Peach
Grass
Walk
options:
A: Walk!  
Explanation: "Walk" closely mirrors the action-oriented nature of both the correct answer "motion" and several words in Group A, such as "drive." However, attempting to apply the given pronunciation rule does not transform "walk" into a new, recognizable word. This selection offers a misleading sense of correctness based on its surface relevance to "motion," proving it to be a clever distractor.

B: Grass!  
Explanation: While "grass" from Group B shares a natural element connection with "peach," suggesting a subtle link to the question's theme, it fails the specific test set by the original answer. Unlike "motion," pronouncing "grass" with its first letter as an individual syllable does not result in a new word, thus making it a crafty, yet incorrect choice.

C: Peach!  
Explanation: By offering "peach" as an option, its initial appeal lies in its contrast to the abstract nature of "motion" yet maintains a tangential connection through a sensory experience (taste/movement). Despite this, "peach" similarly does not comply with the pronunciation rule required to transition it into another word, defining its role as an ingeniously misleading option.

D: Motion

If you pronounce the words in Group A so that the first letter of each word is an individual syllable, you get new words: ceiling, derive, effort, estate.  Only with motion from Group B can the same thing be done: emotion.

problem:
Sandy and Sue each has a whole number of dollars. I ask them how many dollars they have.

Sandy says: "If Sue gives me some dollars, we'll have the same amount of money. But if I give Sue the same number of dollars, she'll have twice as much money as I have."

Sue says: "And if you remove the first digit of my wealth and place it to the end, you'll get Sandy's wealth."

If neither of them has more than 1 million dollars, how many dollars do they each have?
options:
A: Sandy has 256789 dollars and Sue has 678925 dollars.
Let X and Y be Sandy's and Sue's amounts of money, respectively. Let Z be the number of dollars in Sandy's statement.

Then X+Z=Y-Z and 2(X-Z)=Y+Z. Solving this, we get X=4Z and Y=6Z.

According to Sue's statement, let A be the first digit of Sue's wealth, B be the remaining digits, and n be the number of digits, then Y=A*10^(n-1)+B and X=10B+A.

6X=4Y
6*(10B+A)=4*(A*10^(n-1)+B)
(4*10^(n-1)-6)A=66B

Since 66B is divisible by 6 and 4*10^(n-1)-6 is not, A must equal 6. We get:

4*10^(n-1)-6=11B

The least value of n for which 4*10^(n-1)-6 is a multiple of 11 is 5:

49994=4545*11

The next is 11, which makes them have more than 1 million dollars. Hence n=5 and B=4545.

Therefore, Sandy has 256789 dollars and Sue has 678925 dollars.

B: Sandy has 192307 dollars and Sue has 769230 dollars.
Let X and Y be Sandy's and Sue's amounts of money, respectively. Let Z be the number of dollars in Sandy's statement.

Then X+Z=Y-Z and 2(X-Z)=Y+Z. Solving this we get X=3Z and Y=9Z.

According to Sue's statement, let A be the first digit of Sue's wealth, B be the remaining digits, and n be the number of digits, then Y=A*10^(n-1)+B and X=10B+A.

9X=3Y
9*(10B+A)=3*(A*10^(n-1)+B)
(3*10^(n-1)-9)A=81B

Since 81B is divisible by 9 and 3*10^(n-1)-9 is not, A must equal 9. We get:

3*10^(n-1)-9=27B

The least value of n such that 3*10^(n-1)-9 is a multiple of 27 is 4:

2997=111*27

Therefore, Sandy has 192307 dollars and Sue has 769230 dollars.

C: Let X and Y be Sandy's and Sue's amounts of money, respectively. Let Z be the number of dollars in Sandy's statement.

Then X+Z=Y-Z and 2(X-Z)=Y+Z. Solving this we get X=5Z and Y=7Z.

According to Sue's statement, let A be the first digit of Sue's wealth, B be the remaining digits, and n be the number of digits, then Y=A*10^(n-1)+B and X=10B+A.

7X=5Y
7*(10B+A)=5*(A*10^(n-1)+B)
(5*10^(n-1)-7)A=65B

Since 65B is divisible by 5 and 5*10^(n-1)-7 is not, A must equal 5. We get:

5*10^(n-1)-7=13B

The least value of n such that 5*10^(n-1)-7 is a multiple of 13 is 6:

499993=38461*13

The next is 12, which makes them have more than 1 million dollars. Hence n=6 and B=38461.

Therefore, Sandy has 384615 dollars and Sue has 538461 dollars.

D: Sandy has 142857 dollars and Sue has 714285 dollars.
Let X and Y be Sandy's and Sue's amounts of money, respectively. Let Z be the number of dollars in Sandy's statement.

Then X+Z=Y-Z and 2(X-Z)=Y+Z. Solving this we get X=2Z and Y=8Z.

According to Sue's statement, let A be the first digit of Sue's wealth, B be the remaining digits, and n be the number of digits, then Y=A*10^(n-1)+B and X=10B+A.

8X=2Y
8*(10B+A)=2*(A*10^(n-1)+B)
(2*10^(n-1)-8)A=72B

Since 72B is divisible by 8 and 2*10^(n-1)-8 is not, A must equal 7. We get:

2*10^(n-1)-8=16B

The least value of n for which 2*10^(n-1)-8 is a multiple of 16 is 5:

19992=1249*16

Therefore, Sandy has 142857 dollars and Sue has 714285 dollars.

problem: Flossy returned to her apartment one evening to find that it had been broken into and vandalized. Pictures were smashed, personal letters were ripped, furniture was slashed, obscene graffiti written on the wall, and her favourite dresses torn. Flossy told Shadow that she suspected her ex-boyfriend, Sid. Shadow went to see Sid and explained that Flossy's apartment had been broken into. Sid said he knew nothing about it, but would be happy to help catch the person who wrote such nasty things and caused such damage. Shadow spoke with Sid for a few more minutes then told him he was under arrest for the crime. How did he know that Sid was the vandal?
options: A: Sid mentioned the obscene graffiti but denied knowledge of the break-in.
B: Sid expressed excessive interest in the investigation details, more than a typical person would.
C: Sid had no alibi for the time of the break-in, making him a prime suspect by default.
D: Sid couldn't recall the colour of the graffiti, despite claiming to have seen pictures of the damage.

problem:
These two famous sayings have been rewritten into traditional Australian slang. Can you decipher them and rewrite them into correct English prose? Good luck!

1. Make sure you're a dead cert to put your plates of meat in the right spot, then be you'd best not move a muscle.


2. The whole bang lot's ruddy-well hilarious as long as its happening to some other bloke.
options:
A: Ensure your steps are planted firmly before you decide to freeze in place.
- 'steps are planted firmly': similar to putting your feet in the right spot, but lacks the intentionality of choice.
- 'freeze in place': similar to not moving a muscle, yet implies a reaction rather than a deliberate stance.

B: 1. Be sure you put your feet in the right place, then stand firm.
Abraham Lincoln (1809-1865)

'dead cert': a certainty; beyond doubt; a sure winner.

'plates of meat': rhythmic slang for 'feet'.

'right spot': the correct place.

'best be': should be; it's a good idea to be.

'not to move a muscle': stand firm; don't move under any circumstance. 



2. Everything is funny as long as it is happening to somebody else. 
Will Rogers (1878-1935)

'The whole bang lot': Everything

'ruddy-well': an Australian universal intensifying adjective that was inherited from England.

'hilarious': something funny.

'bloke': A typical Australian expression that means a person.

C: Always let your walk do the talking before settling down without moving.
- 'walk do the talking': suggests actions speak louder than words; not directly related to making a decisive stand.
- 'settling down': implies finding a place to stay or relax, not specifically standing firm.

D: Make sure to always land on your feet, then hold your ground without budging.
- 'land on your feet': often means to recover gracefully from a difficult situation, not precisely about positioning oneself deliberately.
- 'hold your ground without budging': closely related but more focused on resistance than the precise act of choosing where to stand.

problem:
Bicycles, tricycles, pedal cars galore
Some have 2 wheels, some 3, some 4
One each they belong to some girls and boys
Eighteen is the number of these toys
If I change 1 tyre a week I fear
To change them all will take me a year
There are half as many cars as trikes
How many of each are owned by these tykes?
options: A: 5 cars, 10 tricycles, and 3 bikes. Assuming there are 5 cars, leading to an overestimation that results in 58 wheels, surpassing the desired count and thus failing to align with the weekly tire change plan.

B: 2 cars, 6 tricycles, and 10 bikes. Starting with 2 cars suggests a logical progression but mistakenly concludes with 48 wheels, falling short of the target to necessitate a year for all tire changes.

C: 3 cars, 9 tricycles, and 6 bikes. Suppose there are 3 cars. This calculation leads to 3 bikes too many, creating a total of 51 wheels, which is insufficient to reach the necessary total for a year's worth of tire changes.

D: Suppose there is 1 car. There are 2 tricycles and 15 bikes. This makes 40 wheels - not enough.
Suppose there are 2 cars. There are 4 tricycles and 12 bikes. This makes 44 wheels.
Each time I add 1 car I get 4 extra wheels. I need 52 wheels so I want 2 more cars.

Answer 4 cars, 8 tricycles and 6 bikes.

problem:
Which country in Group B can be added to Group A?  Why?  It has nothing to do with their spelling or pronunciation.

Group A:  Australia, Denmark, Egypt, Venezuela
Group B:  Bulgaria, Japan, Peru, Sri Lanka, Thailand, Zaire
options: A: Zaire! The countries in Group A are known for their unique wildlife and expansive natural reserves. Australia has the kangaroo and the Great Barrier Reef, Denmark hosts various Nordic wildlife in its forests, Egypt is famous for its Nile crocodiles, and Venezuela is home to unique species in the Amazon. Thus, Zaire, now known as the Democratic Republic of the Congo, renowned for the Congo Rainforest and gorillas, can be added to Group A. Respectively, the capitals of the remaining countries are: Sofia, Tokyo, Lima, Colombo, Bangkok.

B: Japan! The countries in Group A are island nations or have significant islands. Australia is a continent but also considered an island, Denmark includes many small islands, Egypt encompasses part of the Sinai Peninsula, an island-like landform, and Venezuela owns several islands. Thus, Japan, being an island nation, can be added to Group A. Respectively, the capitals of the remaining countries are: Sofia, Colombo, Lima, Bangkok, Kinshasa.

C: Peru! The countries in Group A have ancient civilizations with significant archaeological sites. Australia with its Aboriginal culture, Denmark with the Vikings, Egypt with the Pharaohs, and Venezuela with its pre-Columbian cultures. Thus, Peru, home to the Incan civilization and Machu Picchu, can be added to Group A. Respectively, the capitals of the remaining countries are: Sofia, Tokyo, Colombo, Bangkok, Kinshasa.

D: The countries in Group A have capitals that start with "C".  Respectively, the capitals are:  Canberra, Copenhagen, Cairo, Caracas.  Thus, Sri Lanka, whose capital is Colombo, can be added to Group A.  Respectively, the capitals of the remaining countries are:  Sofia, Tokyo, Lima, Bangkok, Kinshasa.

A, an, and the are all articles.  Of is a preposition.

problem: A man who had never won a game of chess with his friend, one day bet him that he could simultaneously play two chess games with him, and either win one of the games or draw both of them. He made only one stipulation, which was that they alternate their moves on two separate chess boards and that on one board he got to play black while on the other board he got to play white. He said that he was so confident that he would win this bet that he would let his friend play first. His friend accepted the challenge. How was the man able to win this bet?
options: A: The man proposed using a special chess set for one of the games that had pieces with different abilities. He claimed to have mastered this variant and believed it would give him an edge. Throughout the games, he used his knowledge of the special pieces to create situations that were favorable to him on this board, while maintaining a draw on the traditional board.

B: The man used a highly complex series of moves he had memorized from grandmaster games, ensuring that he could outplay his friend in both games simultaneously. By positioning his pieces strategically on both boards, he managed to confuse his friend and gain an advantage, winning one game while drawing the other.

C: The friend opened with a white move on the first board. The man then made the same opening move with white on the second board. The friend made his answering black move on board two. The man then made this same answering move with black on board one. They played back and forth with the man always using his friend's moves on one board as his own moves on the other board. This meant that the friend was playing himself and that if he won one of the games he would lose the other game, or he could draw both games. But, in no way could he win both of the games!

D: The man suggested playing with a modified rule set that allowed for two moves per turn on one of the boards. By carefully planning his moves, he managed to synchronize the game states in such a way that he was always one move ahead on the board where he had the double move advantage, thus securing a win on that board and a draw on the other.

problem:
Willy and Nilly were two friends who were time travellers. They decided to take a round of ancient lands and explore some of their traditions.

As was bound to happen, frequently they landed up flouting the tradition of the time, and in those days, ancient as they were, imprisonment was unheard of. The penalty for any kind of crime was death by hanging!

Their time capsule was programmed for them to stay in the ancient world for 10 days, so they had to be real careful to stay out of trouble.

As luck would have it, Nilly managed to look into one of the ancient men's homes when they were out at work, and the ladies of the family promptly informed the men when they returned.

Sure enough, the next day, Nilly found himself in the public execution area with a noose around his neck! Aghast, Willy was pleading with the King, who had also come to view the execution.

For this teaser's sake, we have to now assume that the King actually spoke and understood English very well! Maybe he was a time traveller too? The mystery remains unsolved to this day! 

Willy was surprised to hear the King laugh and reply in English - "You will be given one chance, one single chance to save your friend. Do you agree?"

Willy readily agreed. The King fished out an ancient scroll from his robes and presented it to Willy."Solve this if you can", he rumbled, "and your friend can go free".

On the scroll was written the following -

A-7,14
B-9
D-16,20
E-10,11,19
F-21
H-6
I-2
L-3,4
N-1,12,18,24
O-17,22,25
P-13
R-15,23
S-8
W-26
Y-5

Can you decipher what this was? Would Willy be able to save Nilly?
options:
A: FRIENDS SHALL NOT PART TODAY
- Here, the numerical values correspond to letters in an entirely different sentence while maintaining the same numerical-to-letter conversion process. It offers a subtly incorrect alternative that maintains relevance to the context of the story and fits the stylistic presentation of the correct answer.

B: If you see the numbers above, the highest is 26. Draw 26 blanks on a paper and put 1-26 below them. Fill them up as per the numbers shown above. For example, fill up 'A' in blank 7 and blank 14 and so on.

The finished message reads -

NILLYHASBEENPARDONEDFORNOW

or

NILLY HAS BEEN PARDONED FOR NOW

Willy thanks you for helping him save Nilly's life! Until next time that is!

C: THE KING'S MERCY SHINES UPON
- This option employs the same deciphering methodology to reveal a message that is contextually aligned with the narrative yet leads to a conclusion that is plausible but incorrect. It retains the detailed format and stylistic elements of the correct answer, ensuring no content overlaps with either the correct answer or the other options.

D: WILLY MUST LEAVE ALONE NOW
- Each letter's number corresponds to its position in a different message decode, creating a separate yet plausible message under the same cryptic structure. This option mirrors the format and presentation style of the correct answer, including the step-by-step process to decipher the code but leads to a different conclusion.

problem:
I hailed from the Isle of Mauritius,
I liked people though they were malicious,
soon I was but one,
then totally gone,
my demise was so terribly pernicious.
options: A: The Passenger pigeon, once the most numerous bird in North America, its population was decimated due to overhunting and habitat destruction. By the early 20th century, the species was extinct, highlighting the destructive impact of human activity on wildlife.

B: I was the dodo, a flightless bird hunted to extinction around the late seventeenth or early eighteenth century.

I am one of at least 784 known species of animals to have become extinct since the year 1500, but many more may have passed unnoticed. Many estimates suggest huge numbers, as many as 50% of all species, will be extinct in just 100 years time.

C: The Tasmanian tiger, a marsupial that was believed to have gone extinct in the 20th century due to excessive hunting and habitat loss. Like the dodo, its extinction marked a significant loss in biodiversity.
D: The Quagga, a subspecies of the plains zebra that was hunted to extinction in the late 19th century. Its unique half-striped appearance made it a target for trophy hunters, leading to its demise.

problem:
There was a millionaire who loved collecting gold. He bought ten solid gold shapes from a man, but the man proposed a bet. He said: 

"One of these shapes is fake. It is made from a metal that looks exactly like gold. The only difference is that it is 1 gram lighter per 10 cubic cm. If you can find the fake, you can have all of the bars for free". 

So the man weighed all of the bars, and to his surprise, they all weighed the same. Because of their strange shapes, he could not simply measure them. How can the man discover the fake without any measuring tools?
options: A: He could use a heat source to gently warm each shape. The fake one would heat up faster or slower due to its different thermal conductivity, allowing identification.

B: He could hang each shape on a very sensitive balance scale. By blowing air across them, the slight differences in air resistance could reveal the fake, as its larger volume might cause a noticeable balance shift.

C: He could examine the gold shapes under different lighting conditions. The one with the slightest difference in color reflection or sheen, perceptible only under specific lighting, would be the fake, as material composition can subtly affect its appearance.
D: He could fill a bucket with water and place each shape in separately. Then whichever makes the water level rise most is the fake, as it would have to be slightly bigger to make it weigh the same.

problem: A man was transporting two similar looking snakes to the veterinarian.  One was the Coral snake, and the other was the Scarlet King snake.  They both had similar colour patterns, which made it very hard to determine which is which (they both have yellow black red patterns).  A big difference is that the Coral is very venomous, while the Scarlet King is non-venomous.  As he got them to the veterinarian building to secure them, he realized they had both gotten out of their cage.  When he saw the first one, he reached down without a second glance, grabbed it, and brought it inside, knowing that if it bit him he wouldn't be poisoned.  How did he know it was the non-venomous snake?
options: A: One difference between the snakes is that the Coral colour pattern has bigger areas of black than the Scarlet king.  The Scarlet King has small stripes of black, while the Coral has large stripes of black, which makes them look different enough to determine which snake is which.

B: He observed that the snake he picked up had a rounder head shape, which is characteristic of the Scarlet King snake. The Coral snake, by contrast, has a more pointed head, which is an adaptation to its venomous lifestyle. This structural difference made him confident in his identification.

C: The temperature sensitivity of the snakes was the key. When he touched the first one, it felt cooler to the touch, indicating it was the Scarlet King snake, as Coral snakes tend to have a warmer body temperature due to their venomous nature.

D: The man noticed the snake he picked had blue eyes, a common trait of the Scarlet King snake, unlike the Coral snake which typically has red eyes. This eye color difference was his clue to knowing it was non-venomous.

problem:
One day, two kids were walking towards their school. When they got there, one suddenly asked the other, "Who died?"

What did the first one notice?
options: A: The first kid noticed that all teachers were wearing black ribbons. Wearing black ribbons is a common sign of mourning and could indicate that someone in the school community has passed away.
B: The first kid noticed that the flag in front of the school was half-mast. When someone important dies, the flag in front of the school goes down to half-mast.

C: The first kid noticed the school's announcement board mentioning a moment of silence. Schools usually observe a moment of silence in memory of a significant or tragic event, which could imply someone's passing.

D: The first kid noticed a group of students gathered silently around a memorial plaque. When the school community is mourning a loss, students often pay respects at memorials dedicated to the deceased.

problem:
5 total bombs in 3 by 4 grid (3 rows, 4 columns):

row 1: ? ? 2 1
row 2: 3 ? ? ?
row 3: ? 1 ? ?

Find the bombs.

Mine Sweeper rules: each number represents the exact total of surrounding mines.
options:
A: row 1: * * 2 1
row 2: 3 - * *
row 3: * 1 2 *

Explanation:
Starting with the same grid notation but diverging in bomb placement.
Step 1: Incorrectly assumes both D and E are bombs.
Step 2: From the incorrect step 1, misinterprets the number of surrounding bombs.
Step 3: Misplaces a bomb in the bottom right, misunderstanding the grid's numeric hints.

B: row 1: * * 2 1
row 2: 3 - 3 *
row 3: * 1 - 2

Explanation:
Follows the original grid but alters bomb positioning based on incorrect logic.
Step 1: Incorrectly assumes the placement of a bomb in row 3, column 4.
Step 2: Fails to recognize the clear indication of bomb placement in row 2.
Step 3: Misinterprets the rule about each number representing the total of surrounding mines, leading to a flawed bomb layout.

C: * are bombs.

row 1: * * 2 1
row 2: 3 3 3 *
row 3: * 1 2 *

Explanation:
Let's rewrite the grid with letters:
row 1: A B 2 1
row 2: 3 C D E
row 3: F 1 G H

Step 1: we know either D or E is a bomb (but not both).

Step 2: From Step 1, we know B or C is a bomb (but not both).

Step 3: From Step 2, we know A and F are bombs.
row 1: * B 2 1
row 2: 3 C D E
row 3: * 1 G H

Step 4: From Step 3, we know C, D, and G are not bombs.
row 1: * B 2 1
row 2: 3 - - E
row 3: * 1 - H

Step 5: From step 4, we know B is a bomb and E is a bomb.
row 1: * * 2 1
row 2: 3 - - *
row 3: * 1 - H

Step 6: Since there are exactly 5 bombs H must be a bomb.
row 1: * * 2 1
row 2: 3 - - *
row 3: * 1 - *

D: row 1: * * 2 1
row 2: 3 3 - *
row 3: - 1 3 *

Explanation:
Beginning with the same grid, this option mistakes the distribution based on neighboring bomb counts.
Step 1: Misreads the 3 in row 2 as indicating a different arrangement of bombs.
Step 2: Incorrectly calculates the number of bombs adjacent to the 1 in row 3.
Step 3: Adds an extra bomb by misunderstanding the minesweeper rules.

problem:
What phrase is represented by the following?

PAL: 9/10
CHUM: 8/10
MATE: 7/10
options:
A: Best friends forever!
Explanation: "PAL", "CHUM", and "MATE" are indeed expressions of friendship, hinting at a close bond that could suggest "best friends forever." However, this choice plays on the idea of perfect friendships without directly acknowledging the numerical ratings given, thus being subtly misleading.

B: Friendship rating!
Explanation: This option takes a literal approach by focusing on the aspect of scoring or rating presented in the question. It subtly implies that the essence of the message could be about evaluating friendship levels, which aligns closely with the numerical aspect of the correct answer but misses the figurative meaning behind "nobody's perfect."

C: Incomplete connections!
Explanation: By focusing on the notion that none of the words received a 10/10, this option indirectly suggests a theme of something lacking or being incomplete. It mirrors the idea of imperfection hinted at in the correct answer but from a slightly different angle, emphasizing the absence of a perfect score rather than the broader notion of inherent imperfection in everyone.

D: nobody's perfect

"PAL", "CHUM", and "MATE" are synonyms of the word "buddy".
None of them received a perfect score of 10/10, so no buddy's perfect (nobody's perfect).

problem:
Using the logical order of numbers listed below, can you guess what the last number in the sequence will be? 

1 
3 
-1 
2 
-3 
1 
-5 
?? 

What is the last number?
options:
A: The last number is : -1 

The sequence starts with the number 1. Each number thereafter follows a pattern of alternating between addition and subtraction, but it might seem the increments increase differently. The numbers are added in a sequence of 2, 3, 5, and subtracted in the sequence of 4, 6, 8, etc., giving an impression of a different pattern. So, the assumption is made that after -5 would come the addition of 6, leading to -1, as -5 + 6 = -1, erroneously interpreting the pattern.

B: The last number is : 0 

The sequence starts with the number 1. Each number thereafter is found by alternating addition and subtraction. Numbers are added in the sequence 2, 3, 4. Numbers are subtracted in the order 4, 5, 6 etc. So basically, the sequence is found as follows: first number + 2 -4 + 3 -5 +4 -6 etc. The final number in the sequence would have 5 added to it, and would be a 0, as -5 + 5 = 0.

C: The last number is : 2 

The series initiates with the digit 1, following which each subsequent digit is derived through an alternating process of addition and subtraction. It appears that the added numbers follow a sequence of 1, 2, 4, misinterpreting the series as starting with an addition. Meanwhile, numbers are subtracted according to the sequence 3, 4, 5, etc. Based on this misunderstanding, the last number is mistakenly determined to be 2, as -5 + 7 = 2, incorrectly applying a non-existent pattern.

D: The last number is : -4 

Beginning with 1, the sequence is thought to progress through a combination of adding and subtracting figures in an inconsistent sequence of 1, 3, 5 for addition, and 2, 4, 6 for subtraction. This misinterpretation suggests that after -5, a subtraction of 1 (following the misunderstood pattern of next adding lower than subtracting) would result in -4, wrongly concluding the pattern as -5 - 1 = -4, overlooking the correct alternating pattern of addition and subtraction with incremental increases.

Dr. Quicksolve stood beside Sergeant Shurshot and watched the television screen intently as Lieutenant Rootumout pushed the buttons on a remote control. Horizontal lines waved across the screen as a fuzzy picture came into focus and revealed a man backing away from a teller's window and walking backwards out the door of the local bank. Lieutenant Rootumout pushed the remote again and said, "Watch as he enters the bank. You get a good look at his face." They watched the robbery unfold. The man entered, looked boldly at the security camera, then proceeded to steal the money. Lieutenant Rootumout then turned off the screen.

"We have arrested a suspect, Izzy Clownen," he said. "You have a clear picture. What's the problem?" asked Sergeant Shurshot.
"Well, he looks just like the robber, but he has an alibi. Several people claimed he was at a bar across the street from the bank at the time of the robbery. They said he was there for two hours drinking. Finally, he got up and left. It seems like he's in two places at once."

"Is he?" said Dr. Quicksolve. "Or is he Dizzy?"

What does Dr.  Quicksolve mean?
options: A: Izzy has perfected the art of being at two places at once through holographic technology.
B: Dr. Quicksolve guessed that Izzy had an identical twin brother named Dizzy. While Izzy was at the bar, Dizzy robbed the bank.
C: Izzy used a realistic mask to disguise himself as someone else while committing the robbery.
D: Izzy had previously recorded himself at the bar and played the footage to create an alibi.

problem:
When fishes flew and forests walked
And figs grew upon thorn,
Some moment when the moon was blood
Then surely I was born.

With monstrous head and sickening cry
And ears like errant wings,
The devil's walking parody
On all four footed things.

The tattered outlaw of the Earth,
Of ancient crooked will;
Starve, scourge, deride me: I am dumb,
I keep my secret still.

Fools! For I also had my hour;
One far fierce hour and sweet,
There was a shout about my ears,
And palms before my feet.
